choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve involved in this test: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

SPECIAL TESTS FOR MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign / Ochsner’s Clasping / Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. Special tests for ulnar nerve injury are:

 

  • Froment’s sign:
    • Test: The patient is asked to make a strong pinch between the thumb and index finger and grip a flat object such as a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. The examiner then attempts to pull the object out of the patient’s hands.
    • Interpretation: There is weakness of the adductor pollicis innervated by the ulnar nerve which would keep the IP joint relatively straight; instead, the FPL muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve is substituted for the AP and will cause the IP joint to go into a hyperflexed position.

 

 

  • Wartenberg’s sign:
    • Test: The patient’s places wrist in neutral and forearm in full pronation and is instructed to perform full extension of all the fingers. Once digits are extended, patient is asked to fully abduct and then adduct all fingers.
    • Interpretation: A positive sign is indicated with the observation of abduction of the 5th digit, with the inability to adduct the 5th finger when extended.

 

 

  • Egawa’s sign:
    • Test: The patient flexes the middle digit & then alternately deviates the finger radially & ulnarly.
    • Interpretation: If the patient is unable to do this Egawa’s sign, the interossei are affected.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Check strength of Biceps Brachii, Corocobrachialis and Brachialis muscles. Check sensation on lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The test image shown in the question is the Pen Test, which is done to diagnose median nerve injury.

questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GCT

 

GIANT CELL TUMOUR (GCT)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Difference between Aneurysmal bone cyst and GCT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. These benign tumors are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are considered to be congenital, but not all of them are diagnosed at birth. Only about 40% of dermoid cysts are diagnosed at birth, while about 60% are diagnosed by five years of age. The dermoid cysts usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. Dermoid cysts occur most commonly on the head and neck. The etiology of dermoid cysts remains mostly unknown. These occur when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development. In the head and neck region, dermoid cysts can most commonly be seen in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • Lower end femur is Mc site for:
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis

questions.text: Most sensitive test for Carpal tunnel syndrome is:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Durkan’s test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common type of nerve compression syndrome.
  • It occurs when the median nerve is compressed at the wrist.
  • The median nerve extends from the upper arm to the thumb.
  • At the wrist, it passes through a structure called the carpal tunnel.
  • Excess pressure on the wrist may cause swelling, which can lead to Carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Tests for Carpal tunnel syndrome:
    • Tinel’s sign: In this test, the physician taps over the median nerve at the wrist to see if it produces a tingling sensation in the fingers.
    • Wrist flexion test (or Phalen test): In this test, the patient rests his or her elbows on a table and allows the wrist to fall forward freely. Individuals with Carpal tunnel syndrome will experience numbness and tingling in the fingers within 60 seconds. The more quickly symptoms appear, the more severe the Carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • Durkan’s test is performed by manual compression of the Carpal tunnel held for up to 30 seconds and recorded as positive if associated with reproduction of distal paresthesias in the median nerve distribution.

 

 

  • Out of these tests, Tinel sign has the highest specificity and Durkan’s test has the highest sensitivity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Phalen’s test. This test is 42-85% sensitive and 54-98% specific.

 

Option C. Tinel’s sign. This test has the highest specificity but low sensitivity for carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option D. Cozen test. This test is sensitive for lateral epicondylitis. Its sensitivity is about 84%.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tinel sign has the highest specificity and Durkan’s test has the highest sensitivity for carpal tunnel syndrome.

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar Nerve Palsy
Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy
Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture
Knuckle bender splint; Median Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly match the statement regarding the splint shown in image:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy

 

  • Cock-up splint is used for radial nerve palsy.

 

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURIES

 

  • Most common nerve damaged in human body.
  • Most common cause: Fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Shaft of Humerus divided into 3 parts:
    • Upper 1/3rd
    • Middle 1/3rd
    • Lower 1/3rd: Radial nerve injured (50%)
       
  • Holstein Lewis sign: Radial nerve injury in lower 1/3rd fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Paralysis of ECRL & ECRB will cause loss of wrist, thumb and finger extension, leading to Wrist drop.
  • Wrist drop occurs in low radial nerve palsy, which spares the elbow and wrist extension.
  • There is also loss of sensation over the dorsum of 1st web space.

 

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment is usually conservative, which includes analgesic medications like NSAIDs; corticosteroid injections; physiotherapy; and immobilization with cock-up splints for 2-4 weeks.
    • The patient recovers within 4 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Option C. Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. Turn buckle splint is used to produce gradual stretching over the contracted joint. It is used to treat stiff elbow and Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.

 

 

Option D. Knuckle bender splint; Median nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question is a dynamic cock-up splint, which is used in cases of radial nerve injuries (wrist drop).

questions.text: Most specific for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bilateral sacroiliitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Bilateral sacroilitis is a hallmark radiological feature of AS and is a key criterion in diagnostic classification.
  • Visible inflammation and structural changes in the sacroiliac joints, especially if bilateral, are highly indicative of AS.
  • This is considered a more specific diagnostic feature than HLA-B27 alone.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most initial symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
  • Radiographic features:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

  • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually, bony ankylosis.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen. 
  • Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B27. While HLA-B27 is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and is found in a large majority of patients, it's not the most specific for diagnosis on its own. The presence of HLA-B27 can be found in a significant percentage of the general population who do not have AS.

 

Option C. Lumbar movements. Lumbar movements are decreased in ankylosing spondylitis, but it is not specific to the disease.

 

Option D. ESR. ESR is a non-specific marker of inflammation. Increased ESR can be present in systemic infections, bone infections, rheumatic fever, tuberculosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is a significant genetic marker and helps in identifying individuals at risk, the most specific finding for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis, particularly in its later stages, is often the presence of definite structural changes in the sacroiliac joints, especially bilateral sacroiliitis, on imaging.

questions.text: Identify the classification used and grade of the shown injury in a child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gartland’s classification Type III

 

The X-ray provided shows a Supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which is classified using the Gartland classification system. The Gartland classification is specifically for supracondylar fractures, particularly in children.

 

  • Gartland Type III refers to a completely displaced fracture, with no cortical contact between the fragments. There may be either medial or lateral displacement, as seen in this case.
  • The Salter-Harris classification is used for epiphyseal plate injuries, not for supracondylar fractures. Therefore, it is not applicable in this scenario.

 

To summarize:

 

  • Gartland Type I: Undisplaced fracture.
  • Gartland Type II: Displaced fracture with the posterior cortex intact.
  • Gartland Type III: Displaced fracture with no cortical contact (either medial or lateral displacement).
  • Gartland Type IV: An intraoperative diagnosis where the periosteum is damaged both anteriorly and posteriorly, requiring more complex reduction techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salter-Harris classification Type III: Incorrect because the injury in question is not an epiphyseal fracture. Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate fractures, not supracondylar fractures.

 

Option C. Gartland’s classification Type IV: Incorrect because Gartland Type IV is an intraoperative diagnosis, which is not apparent in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Salter-Harris classification Type IV: Again, incorrect because this classification system pertains to epiphyseal injuries, and the X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar humerus fractures in children, while the Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate (epiphyseal) fractures.

 

Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus

 

  • Type 1: Undisplaced
  • Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact
  • Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM)
  • Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL)
  • Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)

 

 

Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries

 

  • Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip
  • Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign)
  • Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split
  • Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis,  (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis
  • Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays

questions.text: A young marathon runner is participating in a marathon competition. After running for 100 m, he develops pain at the anteromedial aspect of tibia which was mild to start with, but increased on further running. X-ray was normal. The doctor ordered a bone scan. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shin splint

 

STRESS/FATIGUE FRACTURE

 

  • Stress fracture is due to imbalance between load and resistance of bone.
  • It is of 2 types:
    1. Fatigue fracture: Caused by application of abnormal stress on normal bone.
    2. Insufficiency fracture: Caused by normal activity on weak bone.
  • Sites of Stress Fractures:
    1. Lower Extremity:
      • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck. The most common site is metatarsal neck followed by tibia (proximal third in children, middle third in athlete and lower third in elderly).
      • Tibia stress fracture = Shin splints
      • Femoral neck (inferomedial compression side in young and superior tension side in older patients).
      • Rarely fibula lower end (runner’s fracture).
    2. Upper Extremity:
      • Olecranon is most common site of upper limb stress fractures.
    3. Pelvis and Spine:
      • Pars interarticularis of 5th lumbar vertebral (causing spondylolysis) is commonest in spine.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Load related pain often bilateral
    • The hallmark physical finding is tenderness with palpation and stress.
  • Investigation:
    • MRI provides excellent sensitivity and superior specificity compared to bone scan in differentiating from infections or tumors.
    • Bone scan is preferable for bilateral cases due to feasibility, also bilateral cases go in favour of stress fracture as compared to Infection or tumor and also can scan the whole body.
  • Treatment: Symptomatic with cast and cessation of activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lisfranc fracture. A Lisfranc dislocation is a spectrum of injuries involving the tarsometatarsal joints of the foot. The Lisfranc joint is composed of the articulation between the first, second, and third metatarsals bones, and the cuneiform bones. Injury of the joint can range from complete tarsometatarsal displacement with associated fractures and ligamentous tears to partial sprains with no displacement. Lisfranc injuries are uncommon and are often misdiagnosed. Even when recognized and treated promptly, there is still a high risk for chronic disability and complications. There are two main mechanisms of injury: direct, and indirect. A direct mechanism occurs as a crush injury to the joint from motor vehicle collision or industrial accident. An indirect injury is more common and is often associated with sports participation involving a longitudinal force with the foot in plantarflexion with a medial or lateral rotational force. The patient presents with complaint of midfoot pain with weight-bearing, following an acute injury. The pain worsens by forefoot weight bearing, and the patient may describe pain or difficulty with the push-off phases of walking and/or running. There is pain with abduction and eversion of the forefoot. Pain can also commonly be reproduced with passive pronation or supination of the tarsometatarsal joint. Radiographic findings show misalignment of the lateral margin of the first metatarsal base with the lateral edge of the medial cuneiform, misalignment of the medial aspect of the second metatarsal base with the medial edge of the middle cuneiform, and/or small avulsion fragments a one of metatarsal or cuneiform bones. On oblique view, the medial aspect of the cuboid should line up with the medial aspect of the fourth metatarsal base. The dorsal cortex of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform should be aligned on the lateral radiographs. Lisfranc injuries can be managed operatively. Initial treatment includes reduction, splinting, and elevation. After six weeks, if the patient is non-tender and radiographs are negative, then begin weight-bearing and rehabilitation. If there is any tenderness but no displacement, then the patient should be in a boot or cast for at least another four weeks before starting rehabilitation. Any displacement requires surgical fixation.

 

 

Option B. Jones fracture. A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone that involves the 4th-5th metatarsal articulation. The fracture occurs as a result of significant adduction force to the forefoot with the ankle in plantar flexion. On a plain radiograph, Jones fracture is located at the metadiaphyseal junction, approximately 2 cm (1.5-3 cm) from the tip of the 5th metatarsal and has a predominantly horizontal course. It should not extend distally. Jones fractures are particularly prone to non-union due to being in a vascular watershed zone and take longer than two months to heal. Displacement of the fracture can increase with persistent weight-bearing; therefore, immobilization is important, with a non-weight bearing cast for 6-8 weeks. Indications for non-operative management include undisplaced fractures and fractures in patients with limited activity (i.e. recreational athletes). Operative management is indicated in patients that are elite or competitive athletes or when delayed union has occurred. Management includes either intramedullary screw fixation or open reduction and internal fixation. 

 

 

Option D. Nutcracker fracture. A nutcracker fracture refers to a cuboid bone fracture with associated navicular avulsion fracture due to compression between the bases of 4th and 5th metatarsals and calcaneus bone. The injury usually occurs secondary to the traumatic abduction of the forefoot. This results in loss of the normal lateral column support and excess valgus force upon the medial column that commonly causes rupture of tibialis posterior tendon or avulsion fracture of its attachment onto medial aspect of the tarsal navicular bone. Nutcracker fractures are clinically significant because they can interfere with the medchanical alignment of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shint splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

NUTRITIONAL RICKETS

 

  • In nutritional rickets, the calcium to creatinine ratio in urine is generally low instead of high. 

  • This occurs because rickets is the result of a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, resulting in inadequate mineralization of bone. 

  • In reaction to conserve calcium levels, the body elevates the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the kidneys actively reabsorb calcium, resulting in low urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate. 

  • Thus, the ratio of calcium to creatinine in urine is not elevated in nutritional rickets, reflecting calcium conservation.

  • A high urine calcium to creatinine ratio would suggest hypercalciuria, which is characteristic of conditions like hyperparathyroidismwithout underlying vitamin D deficiency, or certain renal tubular disorders, but not nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: In nutritional rickets, vitamin D deficiency initially leads to decreased calcium absorption and a tendency for low serum calcium. This activates the compensatory mechanism of the body. The drop in serum calcium stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH then acts to increase calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and mobilizes calcium from the bones (resorption). This helps to maintain serum calcium levels within the normal range, at the expense of bone health. So, it is common to see normal serum calcium in many cases of nutritional rickets.

 

Option B. Elevated Parathyroid Hormone: In rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are frequently increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism) as the body attempts to counteract low calcium levels by enhancing calcium resorption from bones and kidneys. This is a hallmark of nutritional rickets and is the body's attempt to maintain calcium homeostasis.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: A key feature of nutritional rickets is decreased serum phosphorus resulting from compromised renal phosphate reabsorption, exacerbated by a deficiency of vitamin D. High levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) have a significant effect on phosphate metabolism. PTH causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate in the urine. This leads to hypophosphatemia, which directly impairs the mineralization of new bone and cartilage, leading to the characteristic bone deformities of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.

  • A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.

  • However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.

  • Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.
  • It affects anterolateral aspect of femoral head.
  • Etiopathogenesis: Idiopathic (most common) – called as Chandeliers disease.
  • Causes:

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Age 20-50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male).
    • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid-induced cases.
    • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction – characteristic feature
    • A characteristic sign is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion - ‘Sectoral sign’ – with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed, it is grossly restricted – due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.
    • X-rays Sclerosed area shows area of necrosis; Crescent sign – Crescentric defect in subchondral area.

 

 

  • MRI is the investigation of choice – Double line sign is seen.
  • T1: Reduced intensity or irregular outline of head.
  • T2: High signal intensity called as double line sign.

 

 

  • Classification system:
    • University at Pennsylvania system:
      • Mild AVN: < 15% of Femoral head involved
      • Moderate AVN: 15-30% of Femoral head involved
      • Severe AVN: >30% of Femoral head involved
         
  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: protected weight-bearing.
    • Pre-collapse stage: Core decompression to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head (Normal Intraosseous pressure = 10-20 mm Hg; 3-4 times in AVN). Drill holes are made in femoral head. This procedure also opens the channels for vascular ingrowths and it is also supplemented with bone grafting (Vascular or nonvascular) or electrical stimulation or bone morphogenic proteins.

 

 

  • Muscle Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyers graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi’s graft) can be fixed in femoral head to augment vascularity.

 

 

  • Rotational osteotomy: To get the intact part of femoral head in acetabulum weight-bearing area (anterolateral aspect of femur head) this is an extensive procedure requiring vascular repair along with it.

 

 

  • Arthritis/Collapse of femoral head: Total hip replacement one of the very commonly done procedure as most patients present at stage of arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB of hip. Initial focus is in the acetabulum. The majority of cases of hip TB presents as painful, restricted movements of the hip, and a limp. It is secondary to primary pathology in lungs, lymph nodes or any of the viscera. Disease usually starts during first three decades. Depending upon the extent of involvement, there can be deformity, shortening of the limb, swelling, pathological dislocations, and sinuses.

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum

 

 

Stage of arthritis

 

Treatment involved Girdlestone excision arthroplasty/arthrodesis/THR.

 

 

Stage I and II are treated with ATT and traction. If required, joint debridement/synovectomy can be done. Stage III, IV and V are treated with ATT and joint replacement/arthrodesis/osteotomy/excision arthroplasty.

 

Option C. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures of the femoral neck put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing ability of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. The patient will complain of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. MRI is more sensitive (100% sensitivity) and specific for diagnosis.

 

 

 

 

Garden’s classification

 

Treatment is done by closed reduction and internal fixation in age < 65 years. In age > 65 years, hemiarthroplasty is done if there is a pre-existing arthritis. If there is no pre-existing arthritis, total hip replacement is done.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

questions.text: A patient complains that he often gets troubled at night during sleep by tingling and numbness that involves his lateral three digits. He further explains that symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Correct regarding the condition is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CTS: Durkan test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is the entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum
  • Clinical features:
    • 8 times more common in females
    • Usual age group is 50 years
    • Burning pain, paresthesia, tingling and numbness in median nerve distribution



       
    • Pain increased by activities, more troublesome at night; relieved by handing the arm over the side of bed or by shaking the arm
    • Clumsiness and weakness in tasks requiring fine manipulation
       
  • Special tests:
    • Sensory symptoms can be reproduced by percussion over the median nerve – Tinel’s sign
    • Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by holding the wrist in full flexion for a minute – Phalen’s test/Reverse Phalen’s test

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • The most specific test for carpal tunnel syndrome is Durkans test – Direct compression over the median nerve – best clinical test – done by holding wrist in slight flexion and directly compressing the nerve by applying pressure to proximal wrist crease for 30 seconds – development of pain, paresthesia or numbness indicates a positive test.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CTS: Froment sign. Froment’s sign is seen in cases of ulnar nerve palsy where the adductor pollicis is paralysed. The patient is made to hold a book between the thumb and the palm. In case of ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will hold the book using the flexor pollicis longus muscle, which will produce flexion at the IP joint.

 

 

This sign is specific of ulnar nerve palsy and will be negative in carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C. Guyon canal syndrome: Froment sign. Guyon Canal syndrome, also known as Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome/ulnar tunnel syndrome/handlebar palsy, is a relatively rare peripheral ulnar neuropathy. It is defined as a compression of the distal ulnar nerve at the level of the wrist as it enters the hand through a space called ulnar tunnel or Guyon canal. The clinical presentation can be purely sensory, purely motor or both depending on the location of the nerve compression. Froment’s sign will be positive in this case.

 

Option D. Guyon canal syndrome: Durkan test. Durkan test is the most specific and sensitive for carpal tunnel syndrome only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with history of fever with bloody diarrhea 2 weeks back, followed by swollen, red and erythematous joints. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shigella

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS/REITER’S SYNDROME

 

  • The patient presents with a classic picture of reactive arthritis. 

  • Reactive arthritis is precipitated by antecedent gastrointestinal and genitourinary infections and manifests as an asymmetric sterile oligoarthritis, typically of the lower extremities.

  • Reactive arthritis occurs most commonly in young men and is associated with HLA-B27 in 80% of patients.

  • Etiopathogenesis:

    • Most cases of reactive arthritis develop within 1-4 weeks after either a gastrointestinal infection (usually with Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, or Campylobacter) or a sexually transmitted infection (with Chlamydia trachomatis or perhaps Ureaplasma urealyticum).

  • Clinical Features:

    • The arthritis is most commonly asymmetric and frequently involves the large weight-bearing joints (chiefly the knee and ankle). 

    • Sacroiliitis or ankylosing spondylitis is observed in at least 20% of patients, especially after frequent recurrences.

    • Triad: Arthritis + Conjunctivitis + Urethritis/Cervivitis (in females)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a common cause of viral gastroenteritis, particularly in infants and young children. Typical symptoms among children with rotavirus infection include vomiting; watery, non-bloody diarrhea; and fever. In severe cases, dehydration, seizures, and death can occur. It is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option C. E.coli. While some strains of E. coli (like enterohemorrhagic E. coli O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea, and some E. coli infections have been linked to reactive arthritis, Shigella is more classically and frequently associated with it, especially given the history of fever and bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Giardia. Giardia is a parasite that causes giardiasis, characterized by watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, gas, and abdominal cramps. It is not typically associated with reactive arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis has been described following enteric infections with Giardia sp. The interval between the preceding infection and the manifestation of arthritis is 2-4 weeks. Post-infectious arthritis has a predilection for joints of the lower limbs particularly the knee and ankle. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Joint infection can occur as a manifestation of gastrointestinal infection from pathogen Shigella. 

  • This is most commonly found, and is called reactive arthritis, which causes joint swelling, pain and erythema. 

  • It is commonly associated with HLA B27.

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) APL and EPB

 

  • Finkelstein test has been shown which helps to diagnose de Quervain’s tenosynovitis (Inflammation of Abductor Pollicis Longus and Extensor Pollicis brevis).

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic.
  • The examiner places patients’ thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction.
  • In positive test, this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the thumb left free is relatively painless.

 

 

  • Differential diagnosis includes scaphoid non-union, arthritis at the base of thumb and intersection syndrome.
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis.
  • The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: A patient suffered from tibial fracture following a road traffic accident. He complained of pain on passive flexion. His posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were palpable, but he had loss of sensation in the 1st webspace. What will be the next step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measure anterior compartment pressure

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign
    • Order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
    • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm. The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.
       
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are:
    • Impending tissue ischemia
    • When the tissue pressure reaches 30 mm Hg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is less than 30 mm Hg (Normal compartment pressure is 8-10 mm Hg and pressure at calf during walking is 200-300 mm Hg).
       
  • A higher pressure is a strong indication that fasciotomy should be recommended.
  • In a hypotensive patient, the acceptable pressure is lower.

 

Extra Edge:

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Reapply cast. Application of cast will further put pressure on the leg compartments. So, this treatment method will not help.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the pain on passive flexion is the first sign of compartment syndrome. Pulselessness is the late feature. So it is advised to measure the compartment pressure first.

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing's sarcoma

 

  • This case presents a teenager (18-year-old) with symptoms of fever, pain, local rise in temperature, and tenderness in the lower limb, along with increased ESR are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Radiological features:
    • The first image shows a layered periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance), which is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The second and third images show a permeative pattern of bone destruction with a soft tissue mass, another hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents (common in ages 10–20).
  • Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, fever, and elevated ESR, often mimicking infection like osteomyelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

questions.text: First deformity corrected in CTEV is:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavus

 

CLUB FOOT/CONGENITAL TALIPES EQUINO VARUS (CTEV)

 

  • Incidence: 1:1000 live births
  • M:F – 2.5:1
  • 50% are bilateral
  • In its most characteristic form, there are four elements of deformity – Equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.

 

 

  • Conservative Management:

 

 

  • First cast in CTEV is applied in supination to correct cavus.
  • Subsequently in kites, one deformity is corrected at a time, adduction first then varus and then equinus (CAVE).
  • In ponsetti method, adduction and Varus are corrected simultaneously and Equinus is corrected at last.
  • Thus in Kites method, one deformity is corrected at a time but in ponsetti adduction and varus are corrected simultaneously, equinus is corrected at end in both.

 

 

Sequential correction

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Forefoot adduction. This is corrected after the correction of the cavus deformity of the foot. (CAVE)

 

Option C. Varus. This is corrected after the correction of cavus followed by forefoot adduction. (CAVE)

 

Option D. Equinus. This is corrected in the last because it is the most resistant deformity. (CAVE)

questions.text: A young female patient complains of low back pain radiating to the right hip, back of the thigh, leg, and ankle after an intense workout of lifting some heavy weights. MRI shows the following finding. Which nerve root is most likely to be involved here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) L5

 

The MRI provided shows a disc prolapse between the L4 and L5 vertebrae, which is a common site for disc herniation. In cases of disc herniation, the exiting nerve root is generally affected. The L5 nerve root is compressed in a typical L4-L5 disc prolapse, as the L5 nerve exits below the L5 vertebra. Disc herniations are usually postero-lateral, meaning the herniated material presses on the nerve root exiting the spinal cord below the level of the disc.

 

In this case, the symptoms described — radiating pain down the back of the thigh, leg, and ankle — are consistent with L5 nerve root involvement, as the L5 nerve innervates muscles in this area and also provides sensory innervation to the same region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S1: An S1 nerve root compression typically causes symptoms in the posterior leg and into the foot, especially affecting the lateral aspects of the foot and possibly the sole. This distribution is less aligned with the symptoms of the patient described, which are more characteristic of an L5 nerve root involvement.

 

Option B. L3: An L3 nerve root compression would cause pain in the front of the thigh, which is not the primary area of concern in this case. The patient’s symptoms include pain radiating to the posterior leg, more aligned with the L5 nerve.

 

Option C. L4: While an L4 nerve root can sometimes be compressed, this usually happens with a far-lateral disc herniation, which is less common than a postero-lateral disc herniation. The described pain in the back of the thigh, leg, and ankle is not typically associated with L4 nerve root compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an L4-L5 disc prolapse, the L5 nerve root is most commonly compressed, causing pain radiating down the back of the thigh and into the leg and ankle.

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal fibular neck

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Trauma to the proximal neck of fibula leads to injury of the common peroneal nerve as the nerve winds around the neck of fibula.
  • The CPN injury causes paralysis of muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, namely tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, EHL, peroneus tertius (deep peroneal nerve), peroneal longus and brevis (superficial peroneal nerve).
  • Paralysis of these muscles causes failure of foot dorsiflexion i.e., foot drop.

 

 

  • There is also sensory loss on the anterior and lateral sides of the leg, dorsum of the foot and toes, and medial side of the big toe.
  • Lateral border of the foot and lateral side of the little toe are unaffected (supplied by sural nerve, formed by tibial nerve).
  • Medial border of the foot and ball of big toe are also unaffected (supplied by saphenous nerve, branch of femoral nerve).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral malleolus: Fracture at the lateral malleolus is Danis-Weber type A fracture of the ankle. In this, there is fracture of the lateral malleolus distal to the syndesmosis. It is usually a stable fracture. It is generally below the tibial plafond, with an intact syndesmosis and deltoid ligament. This fracture does not cause any nerve injury; thus no ankle movement is affected. This fracture has a good prognosis with ankle secured in a splint or cast.

 

Option B. Proximal tibia: Fracture of proximal third of tibia is associated with anterior knee pain (cases operated with intramedullary nailing), non-union, malunion. No nerve is injured with this type of fracture.

 

Option D. Tibial shaft: Tibial shaft fractures rarely cause nerve injury. Surgical fixation of the fracture with plating puts the superficial peroneal nerve at risk. Saphenous nerve can be injured during placement of locking screws. Transient peroneal nerve palsy after closed nailing can cause EHL weakness and decreased sensation of first dorsal webspace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the proximal neck of fibula causes paralysis of dorsiflexion of the foot because around this portion, the common peroneal nerve winds, which supplies the dorsiflexors of the foot.

questions.text: Which drug is used as a first line management for postmenopausal female with osteoporosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases (pyrophosphate analogs) bind to the surface of hydroxyapatite crystals and inhibits resorption.
  • These drugs are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine.
  • Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss (as occurs with estrogen replacement therapy).
  • These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures.
  • These are the drugs of choice in postmenopausal osteoporotic females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raloxifene. Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) act as estrogen antagonist in breast tissue and as an agonist in bone. Raloxifene selectively stimulates estrogen receptor in bone and is used in treatment of osteoporosis. It reduces risk of breast cancer also.

 

Option C. Estrogen. Hormone replacement therapy is the mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis with estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Combined OC pills. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs) alleviate climacteric symptoms and might have a positive effect on BMD. Of note, progestin is the dominant component over estrogen in COCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first line drugs or drugs of choice to treat osteoporosis in post-menopausal females.

questions.text:
True statements about fracture shaft of femur: (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. More commonly in elderly.
  2. Easily managed with Gallow’s traction in elderly.
  3. Associated with pulmonary complications.
  4. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. c & d are correct

 

FRACTURE SHAFT FEMUR

 

  • Men are more likely to sustain a fracture between the ages of 15 to 35, while women begin to show a steady increase starting at age 60.
  • Men are more likely to sustain fracture from automobile accidents or other high-energy mechanisms.
  • Women are more likely to sustain an fracture from ground-level falls.
  • Automobile accidents are more prevalent in the younger population, while ground-level falls are more common in the elderly population, which is attributed to osteoporosis.
  • Treatment:

 

 

a. Management Plan of Fracture Shaft Femur in Adults: 

  1. Interlock intramedullary nailing currently is considered to be the treatment of choice for most femoral shaft fractures.
  2. External fixator is used in open fractures (open injuries).
  3. Delayed union is treated by dynamization of nail (removal of proximal or distal screws or both) and bone grafting.
  4. Non-union is treated by exchange nailing (i.e. introduction of large diameter reamed interlocking nail) and bone grafting.

 

b. Management Plan in children:

  1. Gallow’s traction: < 2 years of age and traction weight < 2 kg of weight can be used.
  2. Immediate or early spica casting is the treatment of choice in children <5 years of age for femoral fractures with < 2–3 cm of initial shortening, and stable fracture pattern.
  3. Femoral fractures with > 2-3 cm of shortening or marked instability, high probability of slipping of reduction and tight thigh swelling in 6 months to 5 years age group, who cannot be reduced with immediate spica casting, require 3-10 days of skin or skeletal traction before casting.
  4. Fixation by enders intramedullary flexible rods and plating can be used in children with multiple trauma, head injury, vascular compromise, floating knee injuries or multiple fracture, preferably in children > 6 years of age.

 

  • Complications:
    • Postoperative complications include fat emboli syndrome, pulmonary embolism, infection, osteomyelitis, malunion, nonunion, and hip and knee pain.
    • Nerve injuries are common and can be due to positioning as well as iatrogenic injury. Pudendal nerve injuries occur from positioning patients with a perineal post. The sciatic nerve can suffer injury in retrograde nailing with excessive traction of the lower extremity or surgical instruments. 
    • Vascular injury to the DFA or SFA can occur after penetration with instruments or implants.
    • Intraoperative fractures may occur, especially of the greater trochanter, the knee.
    • Malrotation is one of the most significant complications. Malrotation of greater than 14 degrees from neutral can alter gait mechanics and efficiency. Patients cope better with internal than with external malalignment.
    • Nonunion is a failure of the fracture to heal or lack of signs of healing for six months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femoral shaft fractures are more commonly seen in young males of age 15-35 years.
  • It is easily managed with intramedullary nailing in elderly.
  • It is most commonly associated with pulmonary complications like pulmonary embolism.
  • Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management in adult patients.

questions.text: Patellar Clunk Syndrome scar is present at superior pole of patella and impinging on: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral component during extension

 

PATELLAR CLUNK SYNDROME

 

  • It is knee popping and catching due to fibrous nodule on superior pole of patella in TKR patients that impinges on femoral component on knee extension.
  • If symptoms are severe, it requires resection of fibrous nodule (arthroscopic/open).
  • Patients complain of a clunking during knee extension, caused by a suprapatellar fibrous nodule that interferes with patella movement.
  • There is an accumulation of scar tissue along the undersurface of the quadriceps tendon, proximal to the superior pole of the patella.
  • The cause of scar tissue is unknown, but may be related to:
    • Direct trauma to quadriceps tendon during patella resection during TKR
    • Impingement of the quadriceps tendon on the femoral component due to an undersized patellar component
  • Scar is entrapped within the intercondylar notch during flexion.
  • It impinges on the femoral component and is forced out of the notch during active knee extension.
  • The painful snap or clunk is usually felt between 30-45 degrees
  • Many patients can be managed without surgery.
  • However, if there are persistent symptoms, surgical excision of the nodule can be useful.

 

OTHER SOFT TISSUE DISORDERS

 

  • Irritation of the lateral facet of the patella: Contact between the lateral facet of the patella and the femoral implant, in the region of the lateral condyle, can cause chronic lateral knee pain.
  • Popliteal Tendon Impingement: After TKA, the popliteal tendon can be irritated by overhand of the femoral condyles, from a posterolateral osteophyte, from residual synovium or extruded cement. Patients complain of discrete posterior knee pain that occurs after a specific point of knee flexion.
  • Protruding Medial Tibial Component: Pain along the medial knee can be from the protrusion of the tibial, including medial collateral ligament irritation. Tibial revision is necessary if pain is intolerable.
  • Nerve Injury: Deep peroneal nerve injury is a rare but reported complication of TKA, caused by compression, ischemia, traction, crush, or laceration. It typically occurs when there is surgical correction of a significant preoperative valgus deformity or flexion contracture of the knee. The infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve (IBSN) is commonly affected after knee replacement. Patients can report numbness (sometimes a painful numbness) along the lateral aspect of the knee for over a year.
  • Complex Regional Pain Syndrome: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome is a very rare consequence of knee replacement. It is characterized by pain disproportionate to exam findings. There is sensory disturbance (e.g., pain evoked by light brushing of the skin, called allodynia), motor impairment (e.g., weakness), and sympathetic dysfunction (e.g., edema, color changes).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The scar of the patellar clunk syndrome after TKR is present at the superior pole of the patella and it impinges on the femoral component of the implant of active knee extension.

questions.text: Intermittent dose of Parathyroid hormone causes risk of:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Intermittent doses of parathyroid hormone (PTH), specifically recombinant human PTH (teriparatide), are used in the treatment of osteoporosis and are associated with several risks and benefits.
  • Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been associated with PTH therapy, but this risk is primarily a concern with long-term continuous exposure rather than intermittent dosing.
  • Mechanism: 
    • Long-term continuous PTH exposure has been shown to increase the risk of osteosarcoma in studies.
    • This is due to PTH's effects on bone remodeling and the potential stimulation of abnormal bone cell proliferation.
  • Teriparatide (intermittent PTH) is used for osteoporosis and involves daily injections of 20mcg for a limited period (usually up to 2 years).
  • Clinical trials and long-term studies have not shown a definitive increase in osteosarcoma risk with this intermittent therapy, but caution is advised as osteosarcoma is a rare complication of intermittent PTH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subtrochanteric Atypical Fracture: Subtrochanteric atypical fractures are a known risk associated with long-term bisphosphonate therapy, not intermittent PTH therapy. Bisphosphonates work by inhibiting bone resorption, which can lead to the accumulation of micro-damage in bones. Over time, this may result in atypical femoral fractures, including subtrochanteric fractures, often with minimal trauma.

 

Option C. Net Loss of Bone Mass: Net loss of bone mass is not a typical outcome of intermittent PTH therapy. Intermittent PTH therapy generally leads to an increase in bone mass and improves bone density, especially when used in conjunction with other osteoporosis treatments. PTH stimulates osteoblast activity, which increases bone formation.

 

Option D. Osteonecrosis of Jaw: Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a condition primarily associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates and other anti-resorptive therapies, not with intermittent PTH therapy. Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a severe condition where the jawbone becomes necrotic due to impaired blood supply, often linked to the suppression of bone resorption. This risk is notably higher with intravenous bisphosphonates and is associated with dental procedures or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma have indicated a potential risk with continuous and intermittent PTH administration, though it is rarely seen complication of intermittent PTH therapy.

questions.text:
A woman presented with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. NSAIDs can improve the symptoms and have disease modifying activity.
  2. Absence of erosion rules out the diagnosis.
  3. It is associated with raised ESR and CRP.
  4. HLA DR4 is related to the prognosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) III, IV are correct

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis
      • Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
         
  • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
    • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Usually DIP is not involved in and is not used for diagnosis but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
    • Lumbar Spine is usually spared.
       
  • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
  • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers
       
  • Treatment:
    • Exercises to maintain muscle strength and joint mobility.
    • NSAIDs
    • Glucocorticoid therapy esp. in vasculitis.
    • Immunosuppressive therapy by leflunomide, DMARDs, methotrexate (drug of choice), anticytokine, etanercept, cyclosporine, infliximab, adalimumab, abatacept.

 

Other Options:

 

  • NSAIDs are anti-inflammatory drugs and not disease-modifying drugs. NSAIDs are used for symptomatic treatment in RA. They have few side effects but also have potential adverse effects like GI bleeding.
  • Bone erosion is a central feature of rheumatoid arthritis and is associated with disease severity and poor functional outcome. Erosion of periarticular cortical bone, the typical feature observed on plain radiographs in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, results from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text: Which tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus on inversion of the foot? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibialis

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is located behind the medial malleolus, and it is palpable when the foot is inverted. This tendon is essential for supporting the arch of the foot and plays a significant role in foot inversion. During the movement of foot inversion, the posterior tibialis tendon becomes more prominent and easier to palpate behind the medial malleolus, which is the bony prominence on the inner side of the ankle.

 

The posterior tibialis tendon inserts on the navicular bone (sometimes referred to as the scaphoid of the foot). This tendon’s attachment helps maintain the foot's arch and aids in foot inversion.

 

Note - Kohler disease is a rare bone disorder that causes osteochondritis of the navicular bone in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibialis: The anterior tibialis tendon is located on the anterior side of the ankle and foot. It is responsible for dorsiflexion (lifting the foot upward) and does not pass behind the medial malleolus, making it unpalpable in this area during inversion.

 

Option B. Extensor hallucis brevis: The extensor hallucis brevis is involved in extending the big toe. It does not run behind the medial malleolus and is located on the dorsum of the foot, so it is unrelated to the action of inversion or palpation behind the medial malleolus.

 

Option C. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon extends the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is found on the anterior aspect of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and is not palpable during inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot and inserts on the navicular bone.

questions.text:
Steps of surgery of DDH in a child < 2 years:(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Capsulotomy
  2. Femoral osteotomy
  3. Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament
  4. Placing the head back into acetabulum
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a → c → b → d

 

DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)

 

  • This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during or shortly after birth.
  • DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malformations of acetabulum or femur.
  • More common in girls usually seen on left side.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment:

    • Surgical approach: 
      • The aim in DDH is to place the head of femur in acetabulum. 
      • Open the joint, identify the acetabulum, cut and rotate the femur and place the head in acetabulum.
    • Surgical procedure:
      • Percutaneous adductor tenotomy is performed in all patients prior to open reduction. 
      • The hip joint is approached superficially between sartorius and tensor fascia lata. 
      • The sartorius is detached from anterior superior iliac spine to improve exposure. 
      • The anteromedial capsule is incised to remove the obstacle to reduction. 
      • The femoral head is identified and ligamentum teres is cut and traced to the acetabulum. 
      • The psoas tendon is identified and tenotomy is done to improve access to the acetabulum. 
      • The acetabular labrum is identified and care is taken to keep it intact and undamaged. 
      • The transverse acetabular ligament is identified and incised to remove the inferior obstacle to reduction. 
      • The acetabulum is cleared of fibrocartilaginous tissue and femoral head is reduced into the acetabulum. 

     

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of surgical procedure for DDH in a child < 2 years of age is: 

Capsulotomy

↓

Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament

↓

Femoral osteotomy

↓

Placing the head back into acetabulum

choices.text: HLA B27 is associated in 90% cases
It is non-erosive and only joints are affected
Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign
Affects males more than females

questions.text: All are true about Ankylosing spondylitis except:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is non-erosive and only joints are affected

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by erosive changes.  
  • AS is not completely non-erosive.
  • Over time, inflammation can lead to erosive changes, especially in the sacroiliac joints and the spine.
  • The inflammatory process in AS often leads to erosion of the vertebrae and the formation of syndesmophyte (bone spurs), which contribute to the fusion of spinal segments.
  • While AS primarily affects the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), it can also involve other structures.
  • Extra-articular manifestations can include enthesitis (inflammation of the sites where tendons and ligaments attach to bone), uveitis (eye inflammation), and in some cases, systemic symptoms like fatigue and anemia.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HLA-B27 is associated in 90% of cases: HLA-B27 is a genetic marker that is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Approximately 90% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis test positive for the HLA-B27 antigen. However, not all individuals with this antigen will develop the disease, and not all AS patients will test positive for HLA-B27. The exact role of HLA-B27 in the pathogenesis of AS is not fully understood, but it is considered a significant genetic risk factor. HLA-B27 positivity is used as part of the diagnostic process and can help in predicting the likelihood of AS in patients with symptoms.

 

Option C. Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign: Sacroiliac joint involvement is often one of the earliest signs of ankylosing spondylitis. The sacroiliac joints are typically among the first to be affected in AS. Early symptoms include lower back pain and stiffness that improves with activity and worsens with rest. X-rays or MRI of the sacroiliac joints can reveal characteristic changes associated with AS, such as sacroiliitis (inflammation of the sacroiliac joints) and eventually, structural changes such as joint fusion.

 

 

Option D. Affects males more than females: Ankylosing spondylitis is more common in males than females. Studies suggest that the male-to-female ratio for AS is approximately 2:1 to 3:1. The disease may present differently in women, sometimes leading to a delay in diagnosis. Women with AS might have a less pronounced spinal involvement and more peripheral joint symptoms compared to men.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is an erosive inflammatory condition in which axial skeleton particularly in the spine and sacroiliac joints and other organs are affected.

questions.text: Which muscle on the other supporting side is problematic when standing on one leg? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluteus Medius

 

  • Normally, when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei (medius and minimus) of the supported side contract and raise the opposite and unsupported side of pelvis. 

 

 

  • If the abductor mechanism is defective, the unsupported side of pelvis drops and this is known as positive Trendelenburg's test.

 

 

  • Trendelenburg's test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism. 
  • It is positive in the conditions in which any of the three — fulcrum (Femoral Head), lever arm (neck length) or power (muscles/nerve) is affected.
  • Causes of Positive Trendelenburg Test:
    1. Paralysis of abductor muscles:
      • Superior gluteal nerve palsy (supply gluteus medius and minimus)
      • Polio
      • Iliotibial tract palsy
    2. Decreased lever arm: Fracture neck femur
    3. Absence of stable fulcrum about which the abductor muscles can act: Dislocation of hip, destruction of femoral head as in Perthes disease, AVN, late stages of TB hip (stage 4 and 5) and septic arthritis.
    4. Tuberculosis of Hip: Trendelenberg's test may be positive in TB hip only in late stages (stage 4 and 5) when the head of femur is destroyed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliacus: This muscle is primarily a hip flexor and doesn't play as significant a role in single-leg stance.

 

Option C. Gluteus Maximus: While important for hip extension, it's not the primary muscle responsible for stabilizing the pelvis during single-leg stance.

 

Option D. Quadratus Lumborum: This muscle helps with lateral flexion of the spine, but its role in single-leg balance is less direct compared to the gluteus medius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gluteus medius muscle is crucial for hip abduction and pelvic stability. 
  • When standing on one leg, the gluteus medius on the supporting side works hard to prevent your pelvis from dropping towards the non-supporting side. 
  • Weakness in this muscle can lead to a Trendelenburg gait, where the pelvis dips excessively on the unsupported side.

questions.text:
Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Ilizarov

  2. Uniplanar frame with one rod

  3. Biplanar frame

  4. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

 

EXTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin.

  • Uniplanar frame with one rod provides the least stability as it can only resist forces in one plane.

  • In uniplanar frame with two rods, adding a second rod increases stability compared to a single rod.

  • Biplanar frame provides stability in two planes, making it more secure than uniplanar frames. It improves the resistance to rotational and bending forces.

  • The Ilizarov external fixator is known for its exceptional stability due to its ring structure and multiple pins. It provides high axial and torsional stability.

  • It is often used for complex fractures and lengthening procedures.

  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done.

  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.

  • Therefore, the Ilizarov fixator offers the highest level of stability among the options listed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:

 

Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

questions.text: Sprengel’s deformity associated with all except: (INICET Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dextrocardia

 

SPRENGEL’S DEFORMITY

 

  • It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect.
  • The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position.

 

 

  • Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue.
  • From the superior angle of scapula a sheet or band-like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

  • It is associated with Klippel-Feil Syndrome/Scoliosis/Spina bifida (Diastematomyelia)/Cervical rib.
  • Clinical Feature: Shoulder and the scapula at a higher level than the opposite one, restriction of shoulder movement.
  • Treatment: There is no definitive treatment available. Surgery (Woodward procedure) is done for cosmetic reasons only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dextrocardia is rarely associated with Sprengel’s Deformity.
