questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

choices.text: Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
Ulnar fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
Ulnar shaft fracture and disruption of superior radio-ulnar joint
Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly defines Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE

 

  • The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex, is called Galeazzi Fracture-dislocation.
  • It is the fracture of necessity.
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.
  • Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female had a fall and had intertrochanteric fracture. This is due to:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Osteoporosis

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
    • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae (Osteoporosis/Osteomalacia)

 

Note: Intertrochanteric hip fractures are the most commonly occurring fractures in the elderly osteoporotic population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteopetrosis. This disease is commonly seen in children. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis, leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant (congenital) osteopetrosis clinically presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Endobones (os in os or bone within bone appearance) and rugger jersey spine are seen on radiographs. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone, which leads to cortical widening and deformity. The diagnostic histological feature of Paget's disease is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. Initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization (Radiologically seen as advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass lesion). 2nd phase of active bone formation and resorption replaces normal lamellar bone with structurally weak woven bone that bend, bow and fracture easily. In 3rd sclerotic (burnt out) phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. It affects men (> 50 years) more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity.

 

 

Blade of grass

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hip fractures are most commonly seen in elderly females due to osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests are used for the evaluation of scoliosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bending forward

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain.
    • If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending as opposed to postural scoliosis.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer.
    • Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test.
  • A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on this X-ray?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patella fracture

 

  • The given image shows a comminuted patellar fracture with the fracture lines visible and moderate joint effusion.

 

 

PATELLA FRACTURE

 

  • Patellar fractures are usually caused by direct trauma, such as a fall from standing height onto the flexed knee or a dashboard impact from a motor vehicle collision.
  • These fractures can also be caused by rapid contracture of the quadriceps with a flexed knee that can lead to loss of the extensor mechanism.
  • Patella fractures account for 1% of all skeletal injuries and 6-9% are open fractures.
  • Male to female ratio is 2:1 and most fractures occur in 20-50 year olds.
  • On inspection, a palpable patellar defect, significant hemarthrosis, and lacerations, abrasions in setting of open fractures are found.
  • The patient has an inability to perform straight leg raise.
  • The extensor mechanism and retinaculum are disrupted.
  • Lateral view radiograph is the best view for transverse fractures. It is obtained in 30⁰ knee flexion.

 

Lateral view showing effusion in the knee

 

  • Axial view is the best view for vertical fractures.

 

 

  • An important differential diagnosis of patellar fracture is bipartite patella which can be mistaken as patella fracture. It shows smooth and regular borders on the radiograph; can be bilateral in 50% cases, and is characteristically seen in superolateral position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibial Condyle fracture: Tibial Plateau fractures are periarticular injuries of the proximal tibia frequently associated with soft tissue injury. Incidence is 1-2% of all fractures. It can be caused in males in age group of 40s due to high energy trauma, and in females of age group of 70s due to low energy falls. Incidence of lateral plateau fracture is 70-80% (due to valgus load), bicondylar is 10-30% (due to axial load), and of medial plateau is 10-20% (due to varus load). In a high energy trauma, there is fracture-dislocation of the medial plateau with soft tissue injuries (meniscus and ACL tear, common peroneal nerve injury). Low energy traumas cause lateral plateau fractures. AP, lateral and oblique radiograph views are helpful; oblique view helps in determining amount of depression. AP view shows depressed articular surface and abnormal joint alignment. Lateral view shows posteromedial fracture lines and abnormal tibial slope.

 


AP and Lateral view showing tibial condyle/plateau fracture

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Severe destruction of the articular cartilage and menisci is a characteristic feature of RA. Bone marrow edema and bone erosion can both also be found, but are less characteristic.

 

 

Option D. Hemarthrosis of Knee Joint: Hemarthrosis is bleeding into a joint cavity. It is best diagnosed with arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis. Traumatic injury is the most common cause of hemarthrosis. Non-traumatic hemarthrosis can be caused by bleeding disorders that are either hereditary or acquired. Hereditary bleeding disorders include hemophilia and inherited coagulation factor deficiency disorders. Examples of acquired bleeding disorders include advanced liver or renal disease, vitamin K deficiency, disseminated intravascular coagulation, or anticoagulation medication use. Post-operative recurrent hemarthrosis is frequently associated with total knee arthroplasty. The preferred initial imaging modality is plain film radiology of the involved joint and surrounding bones. If a fracture is not seen but strongly suspected, further evaluation with a CT scan is warranted. MRI may be able to diagnose ligamentous or other soft tissue injuries as the cause of hemarthrosis. Ultrasound (US) can help identify and characterize intra-articular fluid collections. The synovial fluid from a hemarthrosis may appear red, pink, or brown depending on the cause of bleeding. Aspiration of the joint and subsequent analysis can differentiate simple effusion, hemarthrosis, lipohemarthrosis, and septic arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the comminuted fracture of the patella.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Treatment of femoral shaft fractures can be operative or non-operative.
  • Operative fixation with intramedullary nailing is the gold standard treatment.
  • Other operative techniques include plate osteosynthesis and external fixation.
  • Closed treatment with traction, splinting, and casting may be temporary treatment.

 

Intramedullary Nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing (IMN) is the gold standard of treatment for femoral shaft fractures.
  • Early treatment in a stable patient within 24-48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection, and mortality.
  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • The insertion site of an IMN is outside the zone of injury, preserving the surrounding blood flow and retain the hematoma that contains beneficial bone growth factors.
  • It provides a strong and stable internal fixation that allows for early mobilization and weight-bearing, which is crucial for promoting healing and preventing complications.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure compared to other options like plate fixation, resulting in less tissue disruption and blood loss.
  • It helps in a faster recovery time and a quicker return to daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip Spica: This is a cast that extends from the waist to the toes and is not typically used for femoral shaft fractures due to the limited mobility it allows.

 

Option B. Above Knee Slab: An above-knee slab is a temporary cast that can be used for pain management and swelling reduction but doesn't provide enough stability for healing a fractured femoral shaft.

 

Option C. Above Knee Cast: Similar to an above-knee slab, a cast offers limited stability and wouldn't be suitable for the long-term treatment of this fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The matrix forming the tumor is the cause of calcification.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • It occurs more frequently in males than in females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Characteristic histological feature is malignant cells with osteoid formation. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation-induced sarcoma.
  • Clinical features:
    • Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis, seen in 25% of patients
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

  • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.

 

 

  • MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.
  • A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases; the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.
  • CT scan may be helpful in differentiating osteosarcoma from myositis ossificans or an osteochondroma. The ossification in myositis ossificans is more mature at the periphery of the lesion, whereas the center of osteosarcoma is more heavily ossified.
  • Treatment:
    • It is highly radio-resistant tumor and ideally, treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. GCT. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone with soap bubble appearance. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). Curettage and stripping of the cavity is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: Which movement of the hip is being demonstrated by the examiner in the following diagram?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal rotation

 

HIP MOVEMENTS

 

  • The given image shows the internal rotation movement of the hip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. External rotation.

 

 

Option C. Adduction.

 

 

Option D. Abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows internal rotation of hip.

choices.text: Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip.
Vascular injury is more common in anterior hip dislocation.
Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior.
In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation.

questions.text: Mark incorrect option: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve injury more common in anterior dislocation of hip.

 

 

 

  • “Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip” – this statement is incorrect. 
  • In posterior hip dislocations, the sciatic nerve is at significant risk of injury. This is the most common nerve injury associated with hip dislocations.
  • In anterior hip dislocations, the femoral nerve or obturator nerve can be injured, but these are generally less common than sciatic nerve injury in posterior dislocations.
  • Therefore, stating nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation is false as it is more common in posterior dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular injury more common in anterior hip dislocation. This statement is correct. This is so because the femoral vessels are in close proximity to the hip joint anteriorly, so there are more chances of vascular injury to occur from anterior hip dislocation. Major vascular injuries are rare in both anterior and posterior dislocations. 

 

Option C. Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior. This statement is correct. The incidence of posterior dislocation of hip is around 90%. This is because of the greater strength of anterior ligaments than the posterior ones. 

 

Option D. In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation. This statement is true. The position of the limb when a patient presents with posterior hip dislocation is of Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation i.e., FADIR while in anterior dislocation, it is FABER i.e., Flexion, Abduction and External Rotation. 

 

 

FADIR in posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior dislocation of hip, vascular injuries are more common whereas in posterior dislocation, nerve injury (particularly sciatic nerve) is more common.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cauda equina syndrome

 

CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROME

 

  • Cauda equina syndrome results from compression (squeezing) of the cauda equina – the sac of nerves and nerve roots at the base and just below the spinal cord in the lumbosacral spinal canal.
  • It is a rare but serious disorder, and a medical emergency.
  • The nerves of the cauda equina provide motor and sensory function to the legs and the bladder.
  • Compression of these nerves can interrupt their function, and the effects can be severe.
  • Causes:
    • Lumbar disc herniation (most common)
    • Trauma
    • Spinal tumor
    • Spinal stenosis
    • Infection
    • Vertebral fractures from osteoporosis
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe low back pain
    • Bladder dysfunction such as urinary retention or incontinence
    • Bowel incontinence
    • Muscle weakness or sensory loss in both legs
    • Loss of motor function in legs
    • Loss or reduction of reflexes
    • Saddle anesthesia (inability to feel anything in the body areas that would sit on a saddle)
  • Investigations:
    • Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging: The best method of imaging the spinal cord, nerve roots, intervertebral discs, and ligaments. Since these scans can detect damage or disease of soft tissue, MRIs are valuable in diagnosing the cause of cauda equina syndrome.
    • Myelogram: Procedure that involves injecting a liquid dye into the spinal column. These X-ray and CT images [usually performed with a computerized tomography (CT) scan] can show pressure on the cauda equina from herniated discs and other conditions.
  • Treatment:
    • Cauda equina syndrome is a potential surgical emergency and may require timely decompression surgery to reduce/remove the pressure on the nerve(s).
    • Undergoing early surgery seems to offer the best chance for improvement of sensory and muscle function as well as bowel and bladder function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pott’s spine. Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest symptom (1st symptom). Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for anterior elements is more significant as disease involves the vertebral body (paradiscal) anteriorly. Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier).

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma. Elderly with bone pains, increased ESR and hypercalcemia is multiple myeloma till proved otherwise. Bone pain is the most common complaint for patients with multiple myeloma. In contrast to most bone tumors, other systemic problems, such as weakness, weight loss, anemia, thrombocytopenia, peripheral neuropathy, hypercalcemia, or renal failure, frequently are present at the time of diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Symptoms usually are of short duration because of the aggressive nature of the disease. Pathological fractures are relatively common. The spine is the most common location followed by the ribs and pelvis.

 

Option D. Bone metastasis. The common symptoms include bone pain (frequent symptom), gradual in onset and described as a dull, boring pain that is worse at night. Bone metastases causing nerve root compression can present as radicular pain different from mechanical pain. As the vertebra is the most common site of metastasis, a significant complication includes spinal cord compression, which is an oncologic emergency. Metastatic spinal cord compression occurs either through pathological vertebral collapse or direct epidural extension. Patients may present initially with back pain. Limb weakness is the second most common symptom. Sensory symptoms include paresthesia and numbness at and below the level of cord compression. Autonomic dysfunction, including bowel and bladder incontinence and impotence, is typically a late presentation. In malignancy, hypercalcemia can be multifactorial and confers a poor prognosis overall. Osteolytic bone metastases are associated with 10-30% of the cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy due to enhanced osteoclastic bone resorption. Symptoms include nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, and mental status changes. Bone metastases cause bone destruction, increasing the risk for atraumatic fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presenting symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of cauda equine syndrome caused due to lumbar disc prolapse.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture: (AIIMS Nov 2019)

 

  1. More common in males than females.
  2. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  3. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur.
  4. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct.

 

Explanation:

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR

 

  • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Etiology:
    • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. 
    • The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1.
    • In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb.
  • Treatment:

 

 

  • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture).
  • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail).
  • Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN).
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males.
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

questions.text: Ring sequestrum is associated with which of the following? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) External pin fixator

 

  • A sequestrum is infected dead bone formed as a squealae of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • Ring sequestrum is a low grade chronic osteomyelitis following pintract infection producing an unusual sequestrum surrounded by radiolucent area, another circle of sclerotic bone.
  • Improper aseptic technique of skeletal pin traction, thermal necrosis, prolonged duration, poor pin tract care and comorbid conditions can lead to this complications and presents with skin discharge, pin loosening and osteomyelitis.
  • Thorough surgical debridement, sequestrectomy and saucerisation with appropriate antibiotics and dead space management will successfully treat it.

 

 

TYPES OF SEQUESTRUMS

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation exposure. The response of bone to the trauma of radiation is inflammation. This is seen radiographically as an increase in sclerosis. Irradiated bone has less ability to remodel. Radiation therapy (as well as bisphosphonate therapy) can be considered as macrotrauma that lower the threshold of the ability for bone to repair. Adding in microtrauma events such as dental extraction, denture irritation, break in mucosal protection from traumatic ulceration may lead to exceeding the bone’s capacity to remodel, resulting in necrosis and sequestra formation. When the sequestrum is superficial, bone exposure may occur. When the sequestrum is deeper within the bone, radiographic signs may be the only diagnostic features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring sequestrum is most commonly caused due to external pin fixators, mainly Steinmann pins.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

 

  • The image shown in the question is of high-stepping gait, where the foot drops due to common peroneal nerve injury and while walking, the foot slaps on the ground.

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is one of the two major branches of the sciatic nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The innervation of the superficial peroneal nerve are:
    • Motor:
      • Peroneus longus
      • Peroneus brevis
    • Sensory: Anterolateral leg
  • Deep peroneal nerve innervation are:
    • Motor:
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
    • Sensory: First dorsal webspace
  • The nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck.
  • The most common presentation of a common peroneal nerve injury is a weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and the classic resultant foot drop while ambulating. 
  • Foot drop can develop acutely or over days to weeks, depending on the etiology. It can also be complete or partial in severity.
  • There may also be accompanying numbness or paresthesia present along the lateral leg, dorsal foot, and/or the first toe webspace.
  • Pain may also be present in traumatic cases but is not always present.
  • A patient with weakened or paralyzed dorsiflexors may ambulate with a high steppage gait to prevent dragging of toes on the ground.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Waddling gait. Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, like in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture of the hip joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients have difficulty in standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase. This waddling gait pattern can also be caused when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck. 

 

 

Option C. Circumduction gait. Also called as Hemiplegic gait, circumduction gait is most commonly seen in stroke. The patient stands with unilateral weakness on the affected side with arm flexed, adducted and internally rotated. Leg on the same side is in extension with plantar flexion of the foot and toes. While walking, the patient hold their arm to one side and drags the affected leg in semi-circle or circumduction due to weakness of the distal muscles (foot drop) and extensor hypertonia in the lower limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salmonella

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests acute osteomyelitis, and joint aspirate analysis is likely to reveal Salmonella as the causative pathogen.
  • The peripheral smear findings are indicative of sickle cell anemia, a hematological disorder characterized by a variety of complications such as acute painful episodes, priapism, stroke, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome (presenting as pneumonia-like symptoms with fever, cough, and hypoxia).
  • Acute osteomyelitis is an infection that affects the bone and is more commonly observed in children.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella is often the causative agent.
  • Additionally, other bacteria such as Hemophilus influenzae, E. coli, Streptococcus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa can also cause the condition.
  • The infection can spread through the blood (hematogenous route) or through external sources like open fractures, iatrogenic interventions, or from nearby infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus. It is the most common organism to cause acute/subacute/chronic osteomyelitis, post-traumatic and post-surgical osteomyelitis in all age groups. It also causes acute pyogenic infections of spine.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type. Sternoclavicular joint is one of the rare location for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive stretch

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • In compartment syndrome the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling or numbness. Paresthesia, tingling or numbness occur in the late stages.

 

Option D. Pulselessness. It is also the late feature. Presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lachman’s test

 

The image shows the examiner performing a test where the knee is placed in 20 to 30 degrees of flexion and the tibia is pulled anteriorly. This describes the Lachman’s test, which is used to assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

 

  • The Lachman’s test is preferred over the anterior drawer test for diagnosing ACL injuries because it can be performed with the knee in slight flexion, which isolates the ACL and reduces the influence of other structures. A positive Lachman’s test, indicated by increased anterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur, suggests an ACL tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior drawer test: The anterior drawer test is also used to assess ACL injuries but differs from the Lachman’s test in that the knee is flexed at 90 degrees. In the anterior drawer test, the examiner pulls the tibia forward while stabilizing the leg, but this test can be less sensitive than the Lachman’s test in acute injuries.

 

Option C. McMurray’s test: McMurray’s test is used to evaluate meniscal injuries, not ligamentous injuries. It involves flexing the knee and applying rotational forces to check for a meniscal tear. It is done with the knee in 90 degrees of flexion and involves listening for clicking or popping sounds in the meniscus.

 

Option D. Posterior drawer test: The posterior drawer test is used to assess the integrity of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). It is performed with the knee at 90 degrees of flexion, and the examiner pushes the tibia backward. This is not the test being performed in the image, as the tibia is being pulled anteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lachman’s test is the most reliable physical exam maneuver for diagnosing ACL tears, performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion.

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

 

  • This image shows typical finding on physical examination, which is caused by bulging of the biceps muscle belly after rupture of the biceps tendon, known as Popeye sign or Popeye deformity.
  • The Popeye is a cartoon character with bulging muscles, hence its name.

 

POPEYE SIGN

 

  • Etiology:
    • Due to sudden eccentric biomechanical load is applied with the forearm flexed and supinated, which can cause the rupture of either the proximal or the distal tendon junctions.
       
  • Risk factors: 
    • Older age
    • Smoking habit
    • Usage of certain drugs (corticosteroids, statins).
    • Shoulder overuse (sports or work-related activities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted champagne bottle sign. This sign is seen in Lipodermatosclerosis, also referred to as sclerosing panniculitis or hypodermitis sclerodermaformis, which is a persistent inflammatory disorder characterized by the development of subcutaneous fibrosis and induration of the skin of the lower extremities. The chronic phase of lipodermatosclerosis is characterized by well-defined, circumferential, thick, darkly pigmented, non-tender plaques. These plaques are described as having a firm, “woody” induration, and the sclerotic change with circumferential narrowing of the lower leg and concurrent proximal and distal edema, that produces the classic “inverted champagne bottle” appearance of the lower extremity. The rounded cork of the champagne bottle is symbolic of the edematous foot, the central fibrosis around the ankle represents the neck, and the bottle's body embodies the lymphedema proximal to the area of constriction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. No sensory deficit was found. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

  • Flexion at interphalangeal joint of thumb is caused by flexor pollicis longus which is supplied by anterior interosseous nerve, a pure motor branch of median nerve.
  • It branches from the median nerve in the proximal forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres muscle to run deep along the interosseous membrane.
  • From proximal to distal, it innervates the flexor pollicus longus (FPL), the index and long fingers of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP), and the pronator quadratus (PQ).
  • AIN syndrome is an isolated palsy of these three muscles.
  • It manifests mostly as pain in the forearm accompanied by a characteristic weakness of the index finger and thumb pincer movement.
  • Many cases of AIN syndrome arise secondary to transient neuritis, although nerve compression and trauma are known etiologies as well. 
  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is also a common cause of AIN injury.
  • The most common site of AIN entrapment/compression is the tendinous edge of the deep head of the pronator teres muscle. 
  • True AIN syndrome presentation will present with motor deficits only. 
  • No sensory changes appreciated. There are no numbness, tingling, or sensory deficits.
  • The patient will complain of having difficulty bringing the distal phalanx of the thumb and index finger together.
  • On a physical examination, the pinch grip test is positive. Rather than making the "OK" sign, the patient will clap the sheet between the index finger and an extended thumb.

 

 

  • The patient may also complain of having difficulty forming a fist or the inability to button their shirts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. The effect of trauma on the median nerve depends on the injury site and may involve the palm, forearm, arm, or axilla. The damage to the nerve can lead to motor, sensory, and vasomotor loss. Most injuries to the median nerve occur at the wrist. Traumatic injuries to the median nerve at the wrist can be due to wrist fractures. Nerve damage can range from compression to nerve contusion. On the wrist, the median nerve is exposed to cutting and penetrating injuries. The signs and symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome include thenar weakness, numbness in the radial 3 ½  fingers, and paresthesias, burning-like pain in the distribution of the median nerve. Symptoms can mimic the effects of an injury to the C6, C7 nerve roots. Symptoms are typically worse at night and awaken patients from sleep. There is no triceps or weakness in wrist extension. Carpal tunnel is also distinguishable with the Tinel and Phalen tests. A positive Tinel sign and positive Phalen maneuver are indicative of carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

Phalen’s Test for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

 

Option B. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve. The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve is a terminal branch of the ulnar nerve. It supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin on the ulnar side of the hand. The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist. Mechanism of injury includes local trauma, nerve impingement, lacerations at the wrist and Guyon canal cyst. Characteristic signs of injury to the ulnar nerve is the inability to grip paper between the fingers (Card Test) with ulnar claw hand deformity. The ulnar nerve injury can be characterized by flattening of medial border of forearm, loss of sensation at distal interphalangeal joints of 4th and 5th digit, loss of hypothenar eminence, loss of adduction of thumb, loss of abduction of fingers, clawing of 4th and 5th digits, and sensory, trophic and vasomotor changes.

 

 

Card Test (Palmar interossei – Loss of Adduction)

 

 

Ulnar Claw Hand Deformity

 

Option D. Posterior Interosseous Nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve, The deep branch of the radial nerve dives into the posterior forearm through the heads of the supinator to emerge as the posterior interosseous nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the posterior forearm. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve which innervates the extensor compartment of the forearm. It usually has an insidious onset, often presenting with weakness in finger and thumb extension. However, there is preservation in wrist extension due to the radial nerve innervated extensor carpi radialis longus. It is often self-limiting and resolves with conservative measures. However, symptoms that are refractory to non-operative treatment may require surgical decompression. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome can be present in Monteggia fractures or radial head fracture-dislocations. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnar is weakness. Depending on injury severity, there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In case of supracondylar humerus fracture, presenting with an inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, without any sensory deficit, the nerve most commonly injured is the anterior interosseous nerve, a terminal branch of the median nerve.

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP

 

  • The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. 
  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed.
    • The occupant of the car is thrown forwards and his knee strikes against the dashboard. 
    • The axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction.
    • The force is transmitted up the femoral shaft, resulting in posterior dislocation of the hip. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

  • Radiological features: 
    • The femoral head is out of the acetabulum. 

 

 

  • The thigh is internally rotated so that the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken.

 

  • Treatment:
    • In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. 
    • Closed reduction is the primary and most urgent step in the management of an acute traumatic hip dislocation without associated contraindications. 
    • The sooner the reduction, the lower the risk of complications like AVN. 
    • Open reduction may be required in cases where:
      • Closed reduction fails, usually in those presenting late
      • If there is intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction
      • If the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Such a fragment makes the hip unstable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open reduction. Open reduction is done when closed reduction fails, usually in patients presenting late OR if there is an intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction OR if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight bearing part of the acetabulum. Since the question states "No associated fractures are seen," and it's an acute presentation, open reduction is not the first line.

 

Option C. NCCT pelvis: A CT scan is very useful after closed reduction to check for concentric reduction, identify any occult fractures not seen on plain X-rays (especially small intra-articular fragments or acetabular wall fractures), and assess for incarceration of fragments. However, it is not the immediate next step before reduction in an uncomplicated dislocation, as delaying reduction to get a CT increases the risk of AVN. The priority is to reduce the hip.

 

Option D. Arthroplasty. Hip replacement surgery can be considered if optimal stability is not achieved with reduction and fixation of the associated injuries. It is a definitive surgical procedure, usually performed for severe arthritis or irreparable damage. It is definitely not the immediate next step for an acute hip dislocation in a patient who likely has no pre-existing severe joint disease and no associated fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: A 30-year-man presents with swelling over knee joint. Biopsy reveals mononuclear and giant cells. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

 

  • Lesion with giant cells and mononuclear cells in skeletally mature patient, GCT is the best answer.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Klumpke’s palsy?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Claw hand

 

  • Klumpke’s palsy is the lower brachial plexus injury involving C8 and T1 nerve roots.
  • It is less common, but more severe.
  • It involves weakness of wrist and finger flexors and the intrinsic hand muscles.
  • Sensation is lost on ulnar side of the forearm.
  • There may also be vasomotor impairment and unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
  • Claw hand deformity is the usual outcome.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrist drop. The radial nerve is responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits. Consequently, injury to the radial nerve results in the inability to properly utilize these extensor muscles. As a result, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position. This is known as wrist drop.

 

 

Option B. Ape thumb deformity. Ape thumb deformity is a condition in which the thumb is permanently rotated and adducted, resulting in a loss of its opposable function. This deformity is caused by damage to the distal median nerve, which supplies the muscles that control the thumb. The thumb may also experience limited flexion and extension.

 

 

Option D. Porter’s tip deformity. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (mainly C5, partially C6) causes Erb's Paralysis. This causes paralysis of biceps, deltoid, brachialis and brachioradialis mainly; and supraspinatus, infraspinatus, supinator partially. The muscle paralysis causes the arm to hang by the side in adduction and medial rotation with forearm extended and pronated. This deformity is called as “policeman’s tip” or “porter’s tip hand”.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic deformity of Klumpke’s palsy is Claw hand due to paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles and weakness of wrist and finger flexors.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swelling in hand & wrist. Finger X-ray is given. Identify: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromatosis

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.
  • Medullary cavity, Metaphysical tumour

 

 

  • Most common tumour of bones of hand and feet
  •  5% premalignant
  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome. There are multiple enchondromas all over the body.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith (Calcified superficial veins) = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment: Extended Curettage + bone grafting

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple brown tumor. It has been reported that 2-5% patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have brown tumor (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Bone brown tumor secondary to primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is very rare, which is caused by massive secretion of PTH. First, a large amount of bone calcium is mobilized into blood, resulting in fibrous tissue hyperplasia in bone and leaky hemorrhage. Then, macrophage reactive hyperplasia resulted in phagocytosis of red blood cells and a large amount of hemosiderin is produced, thereby forming a brown nodule. The lesions are usually multiple, most commonly seen in ribs, clavicle, pelvis, long bones and mandibles while others are rare. The radiograph of brown tumor is often characterized by osteoporosis, thinning of cortical bone and multiple localized cystic bone destruction.

 

 

Option C. Multiple osteophytic growth. Osteophytes are cartilage-capped bony proliferations that most commonly develop at the margins of a synovial joint as a response to articular cartilage damage, as seen very commonly in degenerative joint disease. Central osteophytes can develop from cartilage lesions within a joint. They are considered a hallmark of osteoarthritis. Osteophytes may be confused with syndesmophytes and enthesophytes. Small osteophytes are sometimes referred to as osteophytic lipping.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows multiple enchondromas in the hand.

choices.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.
Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.
Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.
Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

 

  • The provided X-ray reveals a clearly defined exostosis, indicating a diagnosis of osteochondroma.
  • Additionally, the hyaline cap thickness of 2cms observed on the MRI raises concerns about the possibility of malignant transformation.

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is the developmental malformation thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap that is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs, a result of development malformation.
  • Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen which usually angle away from the growth plate.
  • Typically, the cap is only a few millimeters thick in adults, although it may be 2 cm thick in a child.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Osteochondromas are found on the metaphysis of a long bone near the physis.
  • They are seen most often on the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation.
  • Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; has enlarged further after skeletal maturity, there is loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma.
  • In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick. (Best evaluated by MRI).
  • Osteochondromas are of two types: Pedunculated and broad- based or sessile.
  • Pedunculated tumors are more common. The stalk is directed away from the physis adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the parent bone.
  • The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap
  • Treatment: 
    • Surgery (en bloc resection-extraperiosteal resection) is indicated for lesion that causes pain, symptomatic impingement on neurovascular structure, compromise of joint function, cosmetic deformity, painful bursa formation and rapid increase in size of lesion or when imaging features suggest malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint. This is not true for an osteochondroma. The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap which is irregular and usually grows away from the growth plate.

 

Option B. Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential. This is not true. The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma and 6% for patients with multiple hereditary exostoses. Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; any further enlargement after skeletal maturity takes place, loss of corticomedullary differentiation takes place. It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma. In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick which can be best evaluated by MRI).

 

Option C. Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone. This is not true. The stalk of the lesion grows away from the physis, adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the corresponding components of the parent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

 

  • The provided image indicates an upward displacement of the clavicle, accompanied by a noticeable gap between the clavicle and the acromion.
  • This suggests potential injuries to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

 

ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT DISLOCATION

 

  • Acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury typically occurs due to a fall onto the acromion.
  • Stability of the AC joint is dependent upon both the AC and coracoclavicular (CC) ligaments.
  • An acromioclavicular joint separation occurs when the clavicle separates from the scapula.
  • It is commonly caused by a fall directly on the ‘point’ of the shoulder or by a direct blow received in a contact sport.
  • AC Joint separation is almost always the result of a sudden, traumatic event that can be attributed to a specific incident or action.
  • The two most common causes are either a direct blow to the shoulder (seen in football, rugby, or hockey), or a fall on to an outstretched hand (after falling off a bicycle).
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling around the joint
    • Pain on movement of the arm
    • Depending on the grade, a bump may be present on the top of the shoulder where the clavicle ends
    • The joint may be very unstable
  • It is classified into type 1 to 6 by Rockwood classification according to the severity of the injury and position of the displaced bones.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment according to the grades include:
    • Type I-III: Conservative management with velpeau bandage. The bandage pushes the lateral end of shoulder downwards and the arm upwards, thus maintaining the reduction.
    • Type IV-VI: Open reduction and internal fixation

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Coracoacromial ligament. Coracoacromial ligament originates from the medial border of the acromion and attaches to the lateral border of the coracoid process. This ligament forms a part of the coracoacromial arch and provides support to the humeral head. Coracoacromial ligament injury is mostly related to trauma or clavicular fracture and isolated injury to the coracoacromial ligament is rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray other knee

 

BIPARTITE PATELLA

 

  • It is the congenital fragmentation of patella.
  • In this condition, the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one.
  • It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance.
  • This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years.
  • In some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

 

 

  • Management usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms like rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles, and reduce stress on the patella.
  • In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella.
  • Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain.
  • In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.
  • With appropriate treatment, most people can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avulsion fracture; cylindrical cast. In avulsion fracture of PCL alone, the non-operative treatment relies on restoration of tibiofemoral relationship with immobilization, followed by physiotherapy. In the first 6 weeks, immobilization and limited weight bearing is achieved using a cylindrical cast in 15° flexion or with posterior support in the form of extension or dynamic anterior drawer brace to prevent subluxation of tibia.

 

 

Option C. Avulsion fracture; wire fixation. K-wire fixation is done for distal phalanx base avulsion fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows bipartite patella which is a congenital fragmentation of patella i.e., the patella is made of two separate bones instead of one.
  • In this condition, it is always recommended to get an x-ray of the other knee also as this condition is bilateral in most cases.
  • It is treated by surgical removal of the smaller bone fragment when the conservative methods fail to provide relief.

questions.text:
True statements in view of septic arthritis are:(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Widening of joint space is there.
  2. Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children and neonate.
  3. Incision and drainage is frequently required.
  4. Kocher criteria used to differentiate from transient synovitis.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All are correct

 

SEPTIC (PYOGENIC) ARTHRITIS

 

  • Refers to Infection of Joint.
  • Septic arthritis word is a misnomer as initially there is only infection of joint and if not treated early then Arthritis (joint destruction) develops.
  • Thus, all sepsis of joints do not cause arthritis only inadequately treated ones do.
  • Etiology and Pathology: The hematogenous route of infection is the most common route in all age groups.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Staph. aureus is the most common organism in neonates.
    • Absent movements of a joint after ruling out trauma in pediatric population is septic arthritis till proved otherwise.

 

 

  • Diagnosis: 
    • X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swellings.
    • The earliest plain film radiographic findings of septic arthritis are soft tissue swelling around the joint and a widened joint space from joint effusion; however, uniform narrowing of the joint has also been described.
    • MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction.
    • Aspiration of joint will help to confirm the diagnosis by culture and sensitivity and can also help to differentiate from transient synovitis.
    • Aspiration also decreases intra-articular pressure and reduces chances of avascular necrosis (AVN) of femoral head.
    • Aspiration shows > 50,000 cells/mL and >75% polymorphoneutrophils in septic arthritis.
    • Culture of the aspirate is the gold standard for diagnosis.
    • Kocher Criterion:
      • To differentiate between septic arthritis and transient synovitis, the predictive value of four original Kocher criteria (fever, inability to bear weight, elevated serum white blood cell count, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate) must be present.
      • Non-weight-bearing on affected side
      • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate > 40
      • Fever > 38.5°C
      • White blood cell count >12,000
  • Septic Arthritis with Negative Cultures – Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and Associates Criterion):

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment options include:
      • Arthrotomy (opening the joint capsule)
      • Surgical drainage (decompression)
      • Synovectomy
      • Antibiotics (2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral)
    • Duration of antibiotics is same as osteomyelitis as usually focus is from the bone.
    • If signs of local sepsis do not abate and synovial fluid analysis does not move to normal within 2 days after treatment, open surgical drainage is indicated.
    • If the purulent fluid becomes too thick to aspirate, open surgical drainage is indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given statements in the question are all correct about the septic arthritis.

 

  • There is widening of joint space.
  • Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children and neonate.
  • Incision and drainage is frequently required to treat the infection.
  • Kocher criteria is used to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis.

questions.text: Which method of measurement of scoliosis has been depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobb’s angle

 

  • This X-ray of spine shows lateral curvature (scoliosis) and angle marked is for its measurement – Cobb’s angle.

 

COBB’S ANGLE

 

  • Most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal scoliosis, on plain radiographs.
  • Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.
  • A Cobb angle can also aid kyphosis or lordosis assessment in the sagittal plane.
  • Measurement:
    • To measure the Cobb angle, one must first decide which vertebrae are the end vertebrae of the curve deformity (the terminal vertebrae) – the vertebra whose endplates are most tilted towards each other. 
    • Lines are then drawn along the endplates (or the pedicles if the endplates are not properly visualized), and the angle between the two lines, where they intersect, measured. 
    • In cases where the curvature is not marked, then the lines will not intersect on the film/monitor, in which case a further two lines can be plotted, each at right angles to the previous lines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kite’s angle. Kite’s angle or talocalcaneal angle is the angle between the lines drawn down the axis of the talus and calcaneus measured on weight bearing foot radiograph. This angle varies depending on the position of the calcaneus under the talus and the stiffness of the foot ligaments. Measurement: midtalar line should pass through/just medial to the base of 1st metatarsal and the mid-calcaneal line should pass through the base of 4th metatarsal. In hindfoot varus, the talocalcaneal angle is < 25⁰; in hindfoot valgus, it is > 40⁰; while in a normal foot, it is 25-40⁰.

 

 

Option C. Bohler’s angle. Tuber angle of Bohler (Tuber-joint angle) is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures. It is formed between a line drawn from highest points of anterior process of the calcaneus and highest point of posterior facet, and a line drawn tangentially to the superior edge of the calcaneal tuberosity. It is normally 20-40 degrees. Flattening/Reduction/Reversal of this angle indicates that the weight-bearing posterior facet has collapsed (intra-articular fracture) or Degree of proximal displacement of the tuberosity (intra-articular and extra-articular fracture both).

 

 

Option D. Gissane angle. Also known as critical angle of Gissane, it is used to evaluate the severity of calcaneal fractures. It is formed by two cortical struts extending laterally, one along the lateral margin of posterior facet and other extending to the beak of the calcaneus. Normally, it is an obtuse angle of 95-105 degree. It increases in intra-articular fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.
