questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was taken to a trauma centre after suffering an accident. An X-ray of her pelvis was taken, and the image below demonstrates an intracapsular fracture neck of femur. In this instance, what is the management?  (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed reduction + internal fixation 

 

  • Intracapsular neck of femur fractures (# NOF) occur within the capsule of the hip joint.

  • The blood supply to femoral head travels in a retrograde direction via the capsule. So, any fracture within the capsule could likely damage the blood supply.  

  • Closed reduction and internal fixation method is favored in younger patients to preserve their natural hip joint.

  • In younger, active patients, the primary aim is always to save their own femoral head and avoid the need for joint replacement if possible. CRIF allows the fracture to heal, maintaining the patient's natural anatomy and biomechanics.

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures increases the risk of AVN of the femoral head. While the initial injury itself can compromise blood supply, a precise and anatomical reduction of the fracture fragments is crucial to potentially restore or optimize blood flow to the femoral head, thereby reducing the risk of AVN. CRIF, if successful, can achieve this without further disturbing the soft tissues and remaining blood supply around the fracture.

  • CRIF involves smaller incisions compared to ORIF, potentially leading to less soft tissue disruption, less blood loss, and a quicker initial recovery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiarthroplasty: This is recommended in patients > 65 years of age with displaced fractures, lower functional demands, or pre-existing hip arthritis.

 

Option B. ORIF: ORIF is often preferred for younger and more active individuals where preserving the femoral head is a priority. While ORIF is also a valid treatment, closed reduction is often attempted first to minimize surgical trauma. If a closed reduction is not possible, then an open reduction may be necessary. Open reduction involves a larger incision and more disruption of the soft tissues around the hip joint which can potentially compromise the precarious blood supply to the femoral head, which is already at risk in an intracapsular fracture. ORIF is usually reserved for cases where closed reduction attempts fail. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a young patient, usually < 65 years of age, the ideal treatment method for intracapsular femoral neck fractures is closed reduction and internal fixation using cancellous screws. 

  • CRIF saves the femoral head by providing stable fixation after reduction, minimizing additional trauma to the already compromised blood supply, and avoiding the long-term complications. 

  • ORIF is usually an option if CRIF fails, and hemiarthroplasty is reserved for older, less active individuals.

questions.text: What will be the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6-8 weeks

 

For injuries like the one shown in the X-ray (fracture at the base of the fifth metatarsal), the typical treatment involves immobilization using a plaster of Paris (POP) cast. Foot injuries, including fractures of the metatarsal bones, usually require a period of 6-8 weeks to allow for proper healing. This timeframe is standard for most metatarsal fractures, ensuring that the bone has adequate time to heal and regain strength. Specifically, fractures like the Jones fracture (involving the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction) or the Pseudojones fracture (avulsion fracture) are commonly immobilized for this duration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fractures of the metatarsals, including those at the base of the fifth metatarsal, are typically treated with a below-knee plaster cast for a duration of 6-8 weeks to ensure proper healing.

questions.text: Indications for surgery (including biopsy) in a patient with Potts spine are all except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cold abscess without neurological involvement

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Imaging:

 

1. Plain radiograph:

 

  • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
  • Reduction of disc space
  • Vertebral body destruction
  • Paravertebral abscess
  • Widening of mediastinum

 

2. CT scan:

 

  • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.

 

3. MRI:

 

  • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
  • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

4. Biopsy:

 

  • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist then, surgery needs to be done.
       
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9–12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18–24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months–1 year).|
       
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
    4. Paravertebral abscess
    5. Spine instability due to kyphotic deformity (kyphotic angles 50-60° or more which is likely to progress)
    6. Pott’s spine resistant to current anti-tuberculosis drugs
    7. To prevent/treat complications like late-onset paraplegia
       
  • Surgical options for most of the cases are anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
  • Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of cold abscess without any neurological involvement is not an indication for biopsy or surgical treatment of Pott’s spine.
  • Neurological involvement which is deteriorating with time is an important indication for surgical intervention.

questions.text: In osteoporosis, serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In osteoporosis, the serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal. The bone density is decreased on the DEXA scan.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female underwent hip replacement. After 1 year, she developed fever and pain in the joint. Radiograph revealed loosening of prosthesis. The implant had to be removed. The histological image of the tissue adjoining the implant is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metallosis

 

  • The microscopic image shows multiple foci of extracellular metal deposits (seen as black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.

 

METALLOSIS

 

  • Metallosis is a rare, potentially fatal complication after arthroplasty characterized by the deposition and build-up of metal debris in the soft tissues of the body, associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices, but it has also been described in non-metallic prostheses.
  • It is defined as aseptic fibrosis, local necrosis, or loosening of a device secondary to metal corrosion and release of wear debris.
  • It occurs due to metallic erosion and release of metallic debris products, which induce massive local cytokines liberation from inflammatory cells.
  • It can present with local/systemic symptoms and signs due to a chronic inflammatory host response.
  • The local effects have been described as pseudotumours or osteolysis.
  • The systemic effects are caused by an immunological response to metal debris, including constitutional symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and malaise, cognitive impairment, haematological abnormalities and neuromuscular changes.
  • Risk factor for the development of metallosis include female gender, bilateral implants, high doses of corticosteroids, renal insufficiency and a suppressed immune system.
  • Its histology is characterized by widespread lymphoplasmacytic and histiocytic infiltration around metal debris, foreign body giant cells, metal particles, extracellular metal deposits and intracytoplasmic debris in giant cells.
  • Treatment consists of surgical revision with replacement of the prosthesis components, complete surgical debridement of osteolytic lesions and bone grafting with allograft chips.
  • Complete removal of all metal debris is difficult and may result in extensive tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma. Melanoma, also known as malignant melanoma, is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes. Melanomas typically occur in the skin. In women, they most commonly occur on the legs, while in men, they most commonly occur on the back. About 25% of melanomas develop from moles. Changes in a mole that can indicate melanoma include an increase in size, irregular edges, change in color, itchiness, or skin breakdown. The primary cause of melanoma is ultraviolet light (UV) exposure in those with low levels of the skin pigment melanin. Those with many moles, a history of affected family members, and poor immune function are at greater risk. Diagnosis is by biopsy. Using sunscreen and avoiding UV light may prevent melanoma. Treatment is typically removal of the melanoma and potentially affected tissue (border around the melanoma) by surgery. In those with slightly larger cancers, nearby lymph nodes may be tested for metastasis. For those in whom melanoma has spread, immunotherapy, biologic therapy, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy may improve survival. 

 

Option C. Ochronosis. Ochronosis is named for the reddish-brown hue of tissue termed "ochre-like". It is inborn error of metabolism. Ochronosis is due to deposition of a phenolic compound – "alkaptons" polymerizing into connective tissue, leading to black urine disease called alkaptonuria. Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, alkaptonuria is an inactive gene, mapped on chromosome 3q21-23 coding for the enzyme homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD). The result is systemic sequestration of homogentisate, that upon the decay to benzoquinone, can irreversibly bind with collagen. Polymerization of this molecule takes on an iridescent dark hue, tinting affected tissue and turning urine black. Aside from just discoloration, these processes can cause degradation, degeneration, and developmental problems in all types of collagen. The earliest sign is from parents who notice infants’ diapers are black in color. This disease can be insidious and manifest later in life. Patients may present with back pain or large joint arthralgias in their post-teenage years or early 30s. Pigmentation of the sclera and pinna of the ear is often seen later in life. Constant tendon ruptures especially with minimal trauma. On physical examination, thickened Achilles tendon and bursa effusions are common. For alkaptonuria, a chromatography assay in the urine for homogentisate can be diagnostic, especially, if the color change is noted after being exposed to the air. A genetic test can determine the existence of the autosomal recessive disease.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman syndrome. Rosai-Dorfman disease is a disease that occurs when the body produces too many histiocytes in the lymph nodes. These histiocytes accumulate in the cervical nodes most commonly. Histiocytes may also build up in the skin, upper respiratory tract, and sinuses. Rosai-Dorfman disease is seldom life-threatening. In many instances, the patient’s symptoms resolve on their own. The majority of patients experience enlarged lymph nodes on both sides of the neck. While often painless, these nodes can swell and grow rather larger. Swelling may also be reported in the lymph nodes of the groin, armpits, and in the central portion of the chest. This swelling may be accompanied by fever. The diagnosis is made following a tissue biopsy from the affected site. Though it is most commonly diagnosed in the first 10 years of life, it is also found in adults, affecting men and women equally. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows extracellular metal deposits (black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.
  • It is associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thomas test

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allis test. The Galeazzi test, also called Allis test, is used to assess hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) and can also be used to assess significant leg length inequality. The examination is performed with the child lying supine and their hips flexed to 45 degrees with knees flexed to 90 degrees, and feet on examining table. In this position, look for symmetry in the level of the knees. Galeazzi’s test is positive if the height of the knees is asymmetrical, and may be due to hip dislocation, DDH, congenital femoral shortening, fracture, other congenital conditions. It is also helpful in determining whether the leg length inequality is primarily from the femur or the tibia and can be used to assess leg length with knee or hip flexion contracture.

 

 

Option C. Ober test. The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB). The patient should be in side-lying with the affected side up. Bottom knee and hip should be flexed to flatten the lumbar curve. Stand behind the patient and firmly stabilize the pelvis/greater trochanter to prevent movement in any direction. Grasp the distal end of the patient’s affected leg with your other hand and flex the leg to a right angle at the knee. Extend and abduct the hip joint. Slowly lower the leg towards the table, adduct hip until motion is restricted. Ensure that the hip does not internally rotate and flex during the test and the pelvis must be stabilized. As allowing the thigh to drop in flexion and internal rotation would 'give in' to the tight TFL and not accurately test the length. If the ITB is normal, the leg will adduct with the thigh dropping down slightly below the horizontal, the test is called negative. If the ITB is tight, the leg would remain in the abducted position and the patient would experience lateral knee pain, the test is called positive.

 

 

Option D. Trendelenburg test. The aim of Trendelenburg’s test is to assess the strength of the hip abductors, specifically the gluteus medius and minimus. It is done when a patient complains of a limp, or hip pain or as part of a normal physical examination assessing gait. If the patient is comfortable to stand alone, stand behind the patient. Alternatively, stand in front of the patient, with their forearms positioned on yours to support them. Ask the patient to lift each foot in turn off the ground. When the patient lifts their right foot, the left hip abductors are being tested. When the patient lifts their left foot, the right hip abductors are being tested. Position your hands on the patient’s iliac crests. Observe carefully if the hip on the unsupported side lifts or droops. If the patient is using your arms for support, you will feel them pressing down on one of your arms if their hip abductors are unable to support their weight. A positive Trendelenburg’s sign (pathological) involves sagging of the pelvis on the unsupported side due to the abductor muscles failing to stabilise the hip towards the weight-bearing femur.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thomas test is used to assess the hip flexor contracture.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Distal pole of scaphoid is the most common carpal bone to undergo avascular necrosis.

 

Reason: Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 
  • Middle third (waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
  • Salient Features:
    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 
    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.
  • Complication: Non-union > Avascular necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. 
  • This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid is retrograde, from its distal end to its proximal end. 
  • At the proximal end, the blood supply diminishes. 
  • This accounts for increased chances of avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment when the proximal pole of the scaphoid is fractured.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring

 

PATELLA FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • The image displays a displaced patellar fracture, and the treatment of choice is Tension Band Wiring.
  • Tension Band Wiring (TBW) is a surgical method to secure the bones in place which are subjected to tension forces.
  • Wires and Screws or Pins are used to create this tension band effect.
  • In two-part fracture of Patella, the pull of Quadriceps on the proximal fragment keeps them apart.
  • In the operation, first the fractured fragments are reduced, fixed with TBW and then the extensor retinacula are repaired.
  • TBW converts distractive forces into compressive forces.

 

 

  • In case if there is comminuted fracture where accurate reduction is not possible, patellectomy is done.
  • Tension band wiring is done using: 
    • Cancellous screws for fracture of Olecranon process
    • K-wires and stainless steel wires for fracture of Patella

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension band wiring is the gold standard treatment for the two-part patella fracture.

questions.text: Diagnose the X-ray as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteosarcoma


Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that typically shows characteristic radiographic features such as the "sunburst" or "sun ray" appearance, which is caused by the tumor's aggressive growth pattern. In addition to this, Codman’s triangle may be visible, which occurs when the tumor lifts the periosteum off the bone, forming a triangular area of new bone formation. The lower end of the femur is a common site for osteosarcoma, as well as other long bones in the body.

 

In the provided X-rays, the sun ray appearance is clearly visible, making osteosarcoma the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondroblastoma: This tumor typically presents with calcifications in the epiphyseal (end) regions of bones, particularly in the upper end of the humerus. However, chondroblastoma does not present with a sun ray appearance.

 

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma: This is another malignant tumor, but it primarily affects the upper end of the femur or pelvis. The X-ray for chondrosarcoma typically shows dense calcifications, but not the sun ray pattern associated with osteosarcoma.

 

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: This tumor often presents with a diaphyseal (shaft) lesion in long bones and can cause an "onion-skin" appearance due to the layered periosteal reaction. It does not exhibit the sun ray pattern seen in osteosarcoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The sun ray appearance and Codman’s triangle in X-rays are key indicators of osteosarcoma, especially in the lower end of long bones like the femur.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

 

The image presented shows a spine injury, and based on the clinical scenario (a patient presenting after an RTA or road traffic accident), the fracture pattern described fits that of a Chance fracture. A Chance fracture, also known as a flexion-distraction injury or seatbelt fracture, typically occurs due to high-force flexion injuries, such as in a car accident where a seatbelt restrains the lower body while the upper body moves forward. This type of fracture involves a horizontal break extending through all three spinal columns (anterior, middle, and posterior)

 

The Chance fracture goes from anterior to posterior, involving all three columns, which is a hallmark feature of this injury. The description matches the flexion-distraction mechanism associated with this fracture.

 

Additional Information

 

Common spine fractures:

 

  1. Jefferson fracture:
    • Also called a ring fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra).
    • Mnemonic: JAT.
  2. Hangman's fracture:
    • Fracture through the interarticularis of the C2 vertebra, causing a slip of C2 over C3 (spondylolisthesis).
    • Mnemonic: H2 (Hangman’s fracture, C2 vertebra).
  3. Whiplash injury:
    • Occurs due to hyperextension followed by flexion (e.g., in a high-speed vehicle accident where the vehicle suddenly stops).
    • Resembles the motion of a whiplash.
  4. Wedge fracture:
    • The anterior height of the vertebral body is lowered while the posterior height remains normal.
  5. Burst fracture:
    • Involves damage to the anterior, middle, and posterior columns of the vertebra.
    • The vertebral body is damaged, involving both the anterior and middle columns.
    • Atlas (Jefferson) fracture is also considered a burst fracture.
  6. Chance Fracture:
    • The force moves from anterior to posterior, going all the way to the spinous process.
    • Involves flexion of the body with a distraction force.
    • Also known as jackknife or seatbelt fracture.
  7. Hinge fracture: A fracture where the skull base is divided into two halves: anterior and posterior.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves damage to the anterior and middle columns of the vertebra, with fragments spreading outwards. While a burst fracture may result from high-energy trauma, the image and clinical description provided in this question are more characteristic of a Chance fracture. The distribution of injury in a burst fracture does not typically extend through all three columns.

 

Option C. Compression fracture: Compression fractures generally affect the anterior part of the vertebra, causing a wedge-shaped deformity, but they do not involve the middle and posterior columns like the Chance fracture. These fractures are often seen in patients with osteoporosis rather than as a result of high-energy trauma.

 

Option D. Fracture of spinous process: A fracture of the spinous process (such as a Clay-shoveler's fracture) usually involves a break in the posterior part of the vertebra only and does not involve the anterior or middle columns. This type of fracture typically occurs from direct trauma or forceful flexion but doesn't match the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

questions.text: Which type of amputation is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Below knee amputation

 

The image shows an amputation where both the tibia and fibula are visible below the knee, which indicates a below-knee amputation. A dissected specimen of the tibia and fibula below the knee was shown, which matches the image provided. Below-knee amputations involve removing the lower limb while preserving the knee joint, improving the potential for prosthetic use and mobility in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Above knee amputation: This amputation occurs above the knee joint, where the entire knee and part of the femur are removed. However, the image does not show the knee joint being amputated.

 

Option C. Chopart’s amputation: This type of amputation occurs in the intertarsal region of the foot, which is not applicable in this image, as the amputation is clearly higher up, below the knee.

 

Option D. Lisfranc amputation: This refers to an amputation at the tarsometatarsal joint, which is also a lower limb amputation but located in the foot. The image shows an amputation above the foot, making this option incorrect.

 

Different types of amputations:

 

  1. Hip disarticulation: Removal at the hip joint (disarticulation from the joint).
  2. Above knee amputation: Removal above the knee.
  3. Knee disarticulation: Amputation through the knee joint.
  4. Below knee amputation: Removal below the knee.
  5. Syme's amputation: Amputation above the ankle.
  6. Boyd's or Pirogov amputation: Involves cutting the calcaneum (heel bone).
  7. Chopart's amputation: Involves the intertarsal area (just above the calcaneum).
  8. Lisfranc's amputation: Involves the tarsometatarsal joint (between the tarsal and metatarsal bones).
  9. Transmetatarsal amputation: Amputation in between the metatarsal bones.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A below-knee amputation involves the removal of the lower limb below the knee joint, preserving the knee, tibia, and fibula, which improves mobility and function compared to an above-knee amputation.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity and history of recurrent tooth abscess. On lab investigation, his serum calcium was normal, serum phosphorus was normal/reduced, serum PTH was normal, and ALP was increased. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A)  Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The key finding in this case is the normal PTH level. In metabolic bone disorders like rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) is often elevated, but in hypophosphatemic rickets, PTH remains normal. The patient also has normal/reduced serum phosphorus, which is another critical feature of hypophosphatemic rickets. Although serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is increased, this can also be seen in other forms of rickets, but the normal PTH differentiates this condition from others like nutritional rickets and Vitamin D-dependent rickets (VDDR). Additionally, recurrent tooth abscesses and bone deformities, as shown in the image, are typical clinical features of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Additional Information

 

Different type of Rickets:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nutritional rickets: In nutritional rickets, calcium may be normal to low, phosphorus is usually low, and PTH is typically elevated. This is inconsistent with the findings in the current case where PTH is normal.

 

Option C. VDDR 1 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 1): This condition involves a defect in the 1-alpha hydroxylation of Vitamin D, leading to low levels of active Vitamin D. Here, phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, which does not match the patient's normal PTH level.

 

Option D. VDDR 2 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2): In this condition, there is end-organ resistance to active Vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), leading to high levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, again differing from the normal PTH level observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP). If PTH is normal in a case of suspected rickets, hypophosphatemic rickets should be strongly considered.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humerus

 

  • The image shows fracture of the upper end of humerus.

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Approximately 40% of metaphyseal proximal humerus fractures are non- or minimally displaced and more commonly require operative treatment as compared to epiphyseal fractures.
  • The peak of these fractures occurs between ages of 10-14 and again at 80-84 years with males more affected.
  • Proximal humerus fractures most often occur upon falling backwards onto an outstretched hand with an extended elbow and externally rotated shoulder or through direct traumatic impact to the shoulder. 
  • The Neer-Horowitz system is the most widely used classification system for proximal humerus fractures in children and is graded by severity of displacement.

 

 

  • On examination, there may be swelling, tenderness, visible deformity, and unwillingness to move the shoulder by holding the arm close to the body.
  • Associated injuries to the brachial plexus, clavicle, and scapula should not be missed.
  • Standard radiographs of the shoulder including AP, and axillary views are generally sufficient to characterize the fracture morphology.
  • The majority of proximal humerus fractures in children can be treated successfully with non-operative management due to the immense remodelling potential of the physis.
  • Neer-Horowitz grade I/II can be successfully treated non-operatively with immobilization in a hanging arm/shoulder spica cast and a sling for 3-4 weeks.
  • Operative treatment should be considered in Neer-Horowitz grade III and IV fractures and greater fracture angulation in older children.
  • Failure of closed reduction should be addressed with open reduction.
  • Fixation options include percutaneous pinning, intramedullary nails, cannulated screws, and plates.

 

 

  • Percutaneous pinning remains the most commonly used fixation strategy.
  • Prognosis in children are generally excellent with both non-operative and operative treatment. 
  • Complications are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicle. The clavicle is one of the most common fractured bones in children. These heal quickly and recover fully. Injuries are usually the result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the force transmitted up the arm. A direct blow to the outer end of the clavicle can be associated with distal third injuries and acromioclavicular joint disruption. The vast majority present with pain, swelling and deformity along the line of the clavicle, and a history of a fall onto an outstretched arm. Fractures of the medial third are usually the result of high impact blunt force to the anterior chest (such as in a motor vehicle accident), and can be associated with neurovascular, pulmonary and cardiac (rare) injuries. Careful airway protection and neurovascular assessment is required. Vascular assessment of the arm should also be performed as the subclavian artery runs close to the clavicle in the middle third. Standard AP with 15 degrees cephalic tilt x-ray of the clavicle will show the fracture in two planes and define displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are easily managed with a sling and analgesia.

 

 

Option C. Scapula. Scapula fractures are uncommon in children. Scapular body fractures are usually the result of high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions or falls. There is a high incidence of associated injuries including other shoulder girdle fractures, rib fractures, head injury, and lung injury, such as pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion. Glenoid fractures are often due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder or a fall onto a flexed elbow with the humeral head being driven into the glenoid. The position of the arm dictates whether an anterior or posterior rim fracture occurs. Similarly, acromion fractures are usually due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder. Coracoid fractures are usually an avulsive injury resulting from pull of the acromioclavicular ligaments or the conjoint tendon. Scapulothoracic dissociation is often due to a severe traction injury. The primary symptom is often pain about the shoulder or back and difficulty with motion. Numbness or weakness may be present with a concomitant brachial plexus injury. The majority of fractures are treated non-operatively. Treatment includes immobilization for 3-4 weeks followed by pendulum exercises and protected range of motion. 

 

Option D. Ribs. Rib fracture in children is caused by a high force injury. Ribs 1-3 are the hardest to break. Ribs 4-10 are typically the most vulnerable while ribs 11-12 are more mobile and therefore, more difficult to break. Since children tend to have more elastic ribs than adults, children are less likely to sustain rib fractures. Therefore, children with rib fractures is a sign of significant trauma and should warrant an investigation of possible child abuse. The physical exam may reveal chest wall bruising, along with bony tenderness to palpitation or crepitus. For simple, isolated rib fractures, conservative treatment is usually adequate which includes appropriate analgesia, rest, and ice. The use of an incentive spirometer should be encouraged to prevent pulmonary atelectasis and splinting. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and discharging pus from right leg for 3 months. Following is the radiograph of the child. Identify the labelled structured:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Involucrum

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Presenting Complaints:
    • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom.
    • The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
    • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
    • Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus.
    • There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
    • Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations.  
    • Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever, etc. are present only during acute exacerbations.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
    • Patchy sclerosis
    • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis
    • Sequestrum: Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues
    • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum. There may be some holes in the involucrum for pus  to drain out. These holes are called cloacae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical.
    • Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.
    • Various surgical options are:
      • Sequestrectomy
      • Saucerisation
      • Curettage
      • Excision of an infected bone
      • Amputation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum. It has some holes to drain out pus, called as cloaca.
  • Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.

choices.text: Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

questions.text: An old lady fell in the bathroom with an outstretched hand. She was managed conservatively. Later on, she developed the deformity as shown in the figure. Most likely fracture sustained was:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Fracture of the distal end of radius at its corticocancellous junction, is commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture.
  • It is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely. Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria. Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
     
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia. The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.

  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.

  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.

  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius. Barton's fracture is the displaced intra-articular coronal plane fracture-subluxation of dorsal lip of the distal radius with displacement of carpus with the fragment. Intra-articular component usually signifies high-energy trauma occurring in young adults, causing shear and impacted fractures of the articular surface of the distal aspect of the radius with displacement of the fracture fragments. The fracture pattern most commonly observed in geriatric age group is extra-articular while the high-energy intra-articular type is most frequent in young adult patients. Melone's classification of intra-articular distal radius fractures:

 

 

 

Intra-articular fractures of distal end of the radius can be difficult to treat, at times, with traditional conservative method. Type I and type II Melone's fracture can be managed conservatively by closed reduction and cast immobilization. External fixation is accepted as superior to plaster immobilization in the young patients with an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal radius. Complex intra-articular fractures in which the articular fragments are displaced, rotated or impacted are treated with open reduction and internal fixation.

 

Option C. Scaphoid fracture. It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. Fullness and tenderness is felt in anatomical snuff box. In adults and adolescents, middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) is more common. Nondisplaced, Stable Fractures are treated conservatively by Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast. Displaced, Unstable Fractures are treated by Headless Screw (Herbert).

 

 

 

Scaphoid glass holding cast

 

Option D. Dislocation of wrist. Wrist dislocations can occur at the radiocarpal joint, the midcarpal joint, the distal radioulnar joint or may represent a combination of these injuries in severe trauma. Carpal instability in the form of lunate and perilunate dislocations are uncommon injuries but can be frequently missed. The majority of carpal instability is centered around the lunate, given its location in the middle of the wrist. Injuries progress from scapholunate instability to lunate dislocation. Perilunate dislocations and lunate dislocations are high-energy wrist injuries involving falls from height, motor vehicle collisions, or athletic injuries. Lunate dislocate anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position. In Perilunate dislocation, the lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally. The most common type of perilunate instability is transscaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation. Median nerve is most commonly involved nerve. The most commonly used method of closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

 

A) Normal; (B) Lunate dislocation; (C) Perilunate dislocation; (D) Normal

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is a classic dinner fork deformity, which is a complication of Colle’s fracture.
  • Colle’s fracture is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females after a fall on outstretched hand.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alendronate

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis.
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

  • Treatment:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Alendronate:
    • Alendronate is approved for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis, steroid-induced osteoporosis, and male osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate belongs to the class of bisphosphonate medications, which aids in the prevention of bone resorption and the promotion of bone density, making it a valuable treatment for osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate is an option for maintaining or increasing bone mass, whereas risedronate is preferred in men with osteoporosis.
    • It inhibit bone resorption at rates 1000 times greater than the effect on bone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium and Vitamin D. They are given along with the bisphosphonates but are not the only treatment choice. Calcium is given at a dose of 1500 mg/day. Vitamin D is given at the dose of 400-800 IU per day. Initially, Vit. D deficient patients are treated with active metabolite 1,25, dihydroxy Vit D3 (short half-life 4 hours and expensive) then changing over to longer lasting and less expensive Vit D2 or D3 (t ½ up to 2½ months).

 

Option B. Hormone replacement therapy. The mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis is estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Repeat DEXA scan after 6 months. The DEXA scan is repeated after 6 months to 1 year after starting of the drug treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology:
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% malignant transformation. This is incorrect. Pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.

 

Option C. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic. This is incorrect. Ground glass opacity of the bone is seen in fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy is the treatment. This is incorrect. The mainstay of treatment of GCT is curettage and stripping of the cavity. More aggressive tumors are treated by excision and bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

A. Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.

 

 

B. Central: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. The collapse may be a ‘wedging’ or ‘concertina’ collapse; wedging being more common.

 

C. Anterior: In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.

 

D. Posterior: This is the least common type. In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra, i.e., the pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process are affected.

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common > central type > anterior type > appendiceal type (involving pedicle, lamina, and less commonly transverse process, 2nd least common is spinous process and rarest variety is synovitis of facet joints).
  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of  neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Psoas abscess can give rise to pseudo-hip flexion deformity
  • Paraplegia occurs most often in upper thoracic region.∙
  • Early onset paresis is due to inflammatory edema, granulation tissue, an abscess, caseous material. It has good prognosis.
  • Late onset paresis is due to increasing deformity or reactivation of disease, bony sequestrum, stenosis of the vertebral canal, fibrosis or vascular insufficiency and has poor prognosis.
  • Sequelae of TB spine is usually bony ankylosis.

 

  • Imaging:
  • Plain radiograph: 
    • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
    • Reduction of disc space
    • Vertebral body destruction
    • Paravertebral abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.
    • Widening of mediastinum
       
  • CT scan: 
    • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
       
  • MRI:
    • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
    • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

  • Biopsy:
    • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.

 

  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: no neural complaint; increased reflexes
    • Stage 2: weakness but can walk with support
    • Stage 3: non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%
    • Stage 4: bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%
       
       
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on non-operative management but if indications of surgery exists  then, surgery needs to be done.
    • Stage-wise Treatment:
      • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly neural examination
      • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly neural examination
      • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily neural examination
      • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting
         
    • ATT: 
      • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
      • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
         
    • Indications of surgery: 
      • Bowel bladder involvement
      • Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
      • No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
         
  • Surgical options for most of the cases aren anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed)

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
     

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.

choices.text: To hold bone fragments with traction
For creating a gap in wound

questions.text: What is the use of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To hold bone fragments with traction.

 

Explanation:

 

BONE HOLDING FORCEPS

 

  • Bone holding forceps are used to manipulate bone fragments in place during surgery.
  • They are typically used in orthopedic procedures, such as the repair of fractures or the realignment of bones.
  • These forceps are designed to grip the bone securely without damaging it, and can be adjusted to apply the appropriate amount of force to hold the bone in the desired position.

 

 

  • They allow for more precise manipulation of the bones during surgery and can help ensure the success of the procedure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To hold bone and plate. For this purpose, a Bone-Plate Holding Forcep is used. They are designed to aid in the reduction of fractures and can help secure a plate in place during installation. Aid in the reduction of fractures such as spiral, transverse, compound, oblique, or butterfly. The clamp can also be used to secure a plate in place while the screw holes are being drilled and screws inserted. The fracture site can also be manipulated with the clamp being used as a lever. It has teeth in the jaws for a better grip and a ratchet locking handle for use on various bone diameters.

 

 

Option C. To cut the bone. For this purpose, a Bone Cutter is used.

 

 

Option D. For creating a gap in wound. Wound Spreader is a specialized device that is used to grasp, retract and manipulate the edges of wounds and incisions, in order to spread the space between them and localize surgical targets with ease.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To hold the bone with traction during the surgical procedure, a Bone Holding Forcep is used.
